Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
You’ll

Capitalization of “You” and “Your” is used by the translator to signify the Russian formal register (Vy, rather than ty).

blades

Ice skates.

explanatory
scratchin what’s smooth

Ice skating on the frozen Volga River.

explanatory
sharps

Ice skates.

explanatory
sharp

A connection between Ilya’s profession and his description of himself.

I don’t need a pair

Ilya is missing a leg, so he needs only one skate.

explanatory
blade

Ice skate.

explanatory
I became, unfortunately, damaged

Ilya is missing a leg. Various explanations for how this came to be will be reported throughout the novel.

explanatory intratextuality
flintlike

That is, immobile because of his disability.

explanatory
glidin

Ice skating.

explanatory
ding

This word/sound recalls the sound of knife-grinding.

sound play
Pozhilykh

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character intertextuality structure religion
keep mutterin under the shaft bow even as far as the Valday harbor

Ostanin notes references to Mikhail Glinka’s “Dream of a Russian in a Foreign Land” (1825), Fyodor Dostoevsky’s Notes of a Writer (1877), and Andrei Bely’s “First Meeting” (1921) (Ostanin, 13).

intertextuality music
Valday

A town located in Novgorod Oblast first mentioned in a chronicle in 1495 and known for the manufacture of bells in eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Mentioned several times throughout the novel (R150, 155, 198, 230, 272/E2, 11, 87, 88, 140, 214).

location Russia intratextuality music setting
castin of bells

Valdai is well-known for its bell manufacturing. Here, Ilya refers to small bells such as those used on horse-drawn sleighs. A buben is an instrument similar to the tambourine. The main difference is that some bubens have metal rings, plates, cymbals, or bells attached. Also mentioned at the end of chapter 2 (“некто нетрезво бьет в бубен” [R163/E25]) and in chapter 3 in one of Yakov’s poems (“Некто с бубном бредет пелесками” [R169/E35]).

explanatory intratextuality music
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location setting foreign language
prolong

Ilya asks whether he can continue with his tale, “prolonging” it. This innocuous question gestures toward his desire to keep telling his story, avoiding death in the process.

language theme
On the fourth Thursday of December

According to E. Iablokov, this period of the year is traditionally known as “wolf season” (волчий сезон) and the Slavic name for December is влченец (волк – wolf) (206). Animal motif.

time motif
Christmas Eve

December 24.

time
walkin from the other side of the river

Movement across the river Itil’/Lethe and the movement from the other side on the night before Christmas suggests the expectation of a new life.

location setting theme
You

Capitalization of “You” and “Your” is used by the translator to signify the Russian formal register (Vy, rather than ty).

recluse

Gury (see below).

character
skated to his maker

Died (set expression). Original Russian: отбросил коньки (otbrosil kon’ki), to throw one’s skates away. Here the phraseologism gets concrete and real (Gury kicked off his skates indeed).

explanatory phraseologism
Mylo—one could say—mukomolovo

Mylomukomolovo, a tongue-twister (non-existent) toponym, that will appear in other chapters also with a slight different name: Milokurekemovo and Malokulelemovo. The paronomastic stress on the words mukà/mùka (flour and pain, according to the accent) will be repeated many times in the novel, underlining the closeness of the two concepts. See R218/E119.

location neologism intratextuality symbol
adder’s tongue

Adder’s-tongue, an ancient, primordial group of ferns. Plant motif.

motif
willow

White willow. Plant motif.

motif
was a hunter

See also one of the epigraphs: “the young man was a hunter.”

intratextuality
postal cooers

He presumably keeps mail pigeons. Animal motif.

motif
correspondence

Ilya’s tale, of course, takes the form of a letter to Pozhilykh, and, close to the end of the novel, Yakov will recount reading other people’s mail with the local postman, Sila Silych, in Note XXVI (R238/E153).

structure intratextuality
Gury

Gury’s first appearance. Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality intertextuality symbol motif
that’s what he was called, as long as we’re on it

Sokolov’s typical device of the “disconnection” among reality and names.

language
amusements

Ilya’s interests above transferred to Gury.

explanatory character
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality intertextuality symbol motif
scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps

Ice skating.

explanatory
sharps

Ice skating.

explanatory
resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one

Gury fell into the ice on the Volga and drowned. Thus, the knife-grinders lost his business, but the undertakers took care of his remains.

character explanatory
provide evidence

Officialiese.

register/style
days of the Archer

Sagittarius (November 22 - December 21). As explained by Sokolov himself, “in the book stars and constellations play mainly an aesthetic role, or, if you will, a decorative role, and there is nothing symbolic to look for in them. The ‘Sagittarius dates’ are just days in November and December, when the cold weather is not so severe, and the ice on the river is thin: skating then is a dangerous business” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

explanatory time
dangerous

As will become clear, many of the characters feel a pull toward death and take unnecessary risks and challenges.

explanatory theme
Shallow Reach shores

The two banks of the river between which the characters continually drift.

setting location
arrange races on the weakenin ice

The men who dwell in this imagined region race across thin ice. Many of the characters feel an attraction toward death, which is manifested in the form of the mysterious dame that visits them, takes them away for three days, and, somehow, results in their death soon after.

explanatory
It happens in the outer darkness, intentionally without heavenly lights, and the folks cut figures as well as they can and hurry- scurry playin catch and chasin each other, without seein the holes and cracks.

The skaters prefer to race in the dark without the aid of lights in order to make the game more thrilling. They attempt to avoid the holes and other dangers lurking on the surface of the frozen Volga River.

explanatory
outer darkness

As opposed to twilight — total darkness.

time theme
without heavenly lights

Characters are often associated with constellations throughout the novel. Here, despite the races occurring under the watch of Sagittarius, there are is no starlight. Constellation-heavens motif.

motif
catch

An old folk game (catch, stovetop), at the beginning of which participants traditionally sing “Burn, burn brightly, so that it does not go out” (Gori, gori yasno, chtoby ne pogaslo). Watch the game being played here. Read the lyrics here. This song will also appear in one of Yakov’s chapters (R252/E180).

Russia folklore music
fraughtful

A situation that is full of “fraught” or fraught with significant implications. Frightful.

language neologism
Nikolay, a lad from, when everythin was said and done, the trash co-op. With the overly familiar nickname Helper

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

religion intertextuality character folklore intratextuality
You

Capitalization of “You” and “Your” is used by the translator to signify the Russian formal register (Vy, rather than ty).

wolf slayer

Sokolov explains: “in the old days, a hunter who beat wolves from a horse with a brush” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

explanatory language
chased the Helper away from the house

Many of the characters are displaced from their homes, often more than once. They feel out of place in this area despite their community and their work. On one level, this theme speaks to Sokolov’s own self-exile when he took up a job as a game warden in the Upper Volga region and subsequently his exile from Soviet Russia. The novel is dedicated to “приятелям по рассеянью” — comrades in exile.

theme self-reference intratextuality character
Helper

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Nikolka/Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

religion intertextuality character folklore intratextuality
Gorodnishche

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location intertextuality folklore theme setting
you, as you can see, are also blind

Ironic oxymoron.

pun irony
concertina

A concertina (an accordion or harmonium). Ilya later refers to this instrument in chapter 6 (R191/E73). Throughout the novel, Ilya mixes up instrument vocabulary and refers to his accordion by various names.

music intratextuality
embarcaderos

A floating pier or railway platform. Both locations-images are relevant to the novel: the characters shuttle back and forth across the Volga River, and Ilya loses his leg to a train. In 1837 the first train appeared in the Russian Empire, connecting Tsarskoe Selo and St. Petersburg. Since then, trains and railroads have become an important theme in Russian literature, relevant still today. From the elite’s means of transportation (see the train scenes in Lev Tolstoy’s Anna Karenina, for example) to popular commutes (see Zoshchenko’s short story “A Pleasant Meeting,” Venedikt Yerofeev’s masterpiece Moscow to the End of the Line, or the recent book by Dmitry Danilov Empty Trains 2022), trains have represented an essential trait of everyday life. In Sokolov’s oeuvre trains and railroads occupy a key place, as D.B. Johnson convincingly demonstrated in his 1986 article “Sasha Sokolov’s Twilight Cosmos: Themes and Motifs”: the river and the railroad are the central themes in Sokolov’s literary world, as they connect all other themes (time, death, memory, and sex). Railroad theme.

setting theme location
Nikolay Helperov

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Nikolka/Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

religion intertextuality character folklore intratextuality
his entire shriveled height

Ironic oxymoron.

pun irony
overseas

Ilya and Orina will have encounters with sailors later in the novel.

intratextuality
musick

Archaic spelling of music. Continues the sickness theme (in the translation).

archaism theme
stepped into his shoes

In the Russian original: A variation of the set expression “vlezt’ v shkuru” (get under the skin), meaning “to put oneself into one’s shoes”. Literally, the word “shkura” refers to animal skin, and it anticipates the role that fox fur will play later on in the novel. Animal motif. As Johnson notes, Ilya Zynzyrella, evoking “Cinderella of vair (or verre) slipper fame” is indeed “a male Cinderella [who] makes fur slippers for his beloved who (posthumously) seeks to be reunited with him.” He adds: “If the fur slippers are central to the intergrading of Orina and the mentally defective girls, valenki ‘felt boots’ strongly hint at the relationship between Il’ya and Yakov. It is here that we find echoes of the Oedipus legend” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 164). Shoe motif.

phraseologism motif
splashed wholeheartedly

Ostanin suggests that Nikolai and the itinerants begin drinking (15). Alcohol theme.

theme explanatory
Live, brother, forever

Compare to “Life-Everlastin’” (Вечная Жизнь), one of Orina’s forms and a manifestation of the Volga, which first appears in chapter 10.

intratextuality theme
this dame

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Helper

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Nikolka/Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

religion intertextuality character folklore intratextuality
Nikolka

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Nikolka/Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character religion intertextuality intratextuality folklore
dame

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Helper

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Nikolka/Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character religion intertextuality intratextuality folklore
do not live, brother, forever

Compare to “Life-Everlastin’” (Вечная Жизнь), one of Orina’s forms and a manifestation of the Volga, which first appears in chapter 10. An echo-repetition of their first welcoming to Nikolai a few lines above: “Live, brother, forever.”

intratextuality theme character
mute

Nikolai is, apparently, blind, deaf, and mute. Caramitti talks about an “infinite gallery of crippled” (бесконечная галерея калек) in Sokolov’s oeuvre (“Mul’tfil’m” 363). Two of Sokolov’s early stories were about the blind as well: “The Old Helmsman” (“Staryi shturman”) and “All the Colors of the Rainbow” (“Vse tsveta radugi”). Elena Kravchenko notes a parallel between this theme in Sokolov’s first published stories and the nature of his writing in general: “They were published in Braille, the language by which corporality took the centre stage, outlasting the artefact of reality: not its expression but its embodiment” (The Prose 2).

character intertextuality self-reference
he didn’t shine there with excessively long service

He did not live long there.

explanatory
This is, if You don’t mind, this chronicle

An echo-repetition of how this part of the story began: “What is the chronicle of his failures, if You don’t mind?” A folkloric conclusion combined with the high style of “chronicle.”

register/style folklore intratextuality
You

Capitalization of “You” and “Your” is used by the translator to signify the Russian formal register (Vy, rather than ty).

You don’t mind

An example of Ilya’s conversational style/tone. Why would Pozhilykh object to Ilya’s account of Nikolai’s life?

register/style
unsharpened ones

Ice skates.

explanatory
I and nobody else from the entire collective

A continuation of the individual/collective theme.

theme
turned up their noses, even though they themselves were pachoolies

The other men refuse to serve Nikolai and turn up their noses. Ilya compares them to patchouli, a flowering plant known for its strong smell that is often used medicinally. Plant motif.

motif explanatory
pachoolies

A species of plant in the Lamiaceae family (commonly names: mint and deadnettle). Known for its earthy, musky, woody smell. Characters throughout the novel are frequently associated with flora and fauna. Plant motif.

motif
not of the first freshness

Ilya refers to their age/experience.

explanatory
sharpened

Here and further, the repetition of the verb defines the rhythm, like a refrain.

poetic device
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality intertextuality symbol motif
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality
Wintry Man

According to Boguslawski’s annotations, zimar’ (Wintry Man) refers to Andrei Voznesensky’s poem “Song-travesty from the spectacle ‘Antiworlds’” (1963) (“Annotations” 233). It combines the word zima (winter) with the ending of ianvar’ (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

character intertextuality time
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location setting foreign language
You

Capitalization of “You” and “Your” is used by the translator to signify the Russian formal register (Vy, rather than ty).

Gury the Hunter

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality intertextuality symbol motif
slick

The frozen Volga River.

setting location explanatory
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality intertextuality symbol motif
wine

The characters are all prone to excessive drinking. Alcohol theme.

theme
boot

A shoe with a slight heel, boot, and curved toe. Yakov mentions in Note 2 that the “lonesome babe” chides him for abandoning his boots (R165/E29). D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intratextuality motif intertextuality
rasp

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

foreign
rasp

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

foreign
snagged it

The first of several potential thefts that play a central role in the novel.

theme
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intertextuality intratextuality symbol motif
strument

Instrument: the grinding tool.

explanatory
rasp

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

foreign
rasp

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

foreign
Sloboda

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

location Russia
crashbaret

A drinking establishment. Original Russia: кубаре (kubare). A mixture of kubarem (to fall head over heels) and the French “cabaret.” Customers, of course, will fall over and crash to the floor if they drink too much. The name of the establishment is literalized in this way. On Sokolov’s use of neologisms, see Brainina.

language neologism setting location
verstas

An obsolete Russian unit of measurement equivalent to approximately .66 miles.

explanatory Russia
Sloboda

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

location Russia
rasp

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

foreign
crasp

According to Boguslawski: “crappy rasp” (233).

explanatory
victim of the wager

A possible reference to Lermontov’s poem “Epiphany.” Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality
trundlin in a sack on his mighty hump glasswear collected in the dales and in the hills

Ilya is carrying with him a number of empty glass bottles, presumably to sell. Alcohol theme.

explanatory theme
hump

Ilya is hunchbacked. The image of humpbacked people and animals appears several times throughout the novel (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208).

explanatory intratextuality character
glasswear

glassware

the dales and in the hills

Borrowed from a Soviet Civil War song: “Through Valleys and Over Hills”: “Through valleys and over hills / The division went on.” A recording is available here.

intertextuality music
hills

Mirror Ilya’s hunch.

explanatory
perhaps You’re still completely out of the loop

Ilya’s letter, of course, is written to Pozhilykh, but such statements often seem to address the reader directly.

explanatory
You’re

Capitalization of “You” and “Your” is used by the translator to signify the Russian formal register (Vy, rather than ty).

hasten to give You advance notice

Archaic/officialese: to notify in advance.

register/style
You

Capitalization of “You” and “Your” is used by the translator to signify the Russian formal register (Vy, rather than ty).

crashbaret

A drinking establishment. Original Russia: кубаре (kubare). A mixture of kubarem (to fall head over heels) and the French “cabaret.” Customers, of course, will fall over and crash to the floor if they drink too much. The name of the establishment is literalized in this way. On Sokolov’s use of neologisms, see Brainina.

language neologism setting location
And Gury

A continuation of Gury’s conversation with the other grinders from above, interrupted by Ilya’s commentary on commerce in the region.

explanatory structure
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality motif
rasp

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

foreign
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
rasp

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

foreign
Pozhilykh

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character intertextuality structure religion
marathon whiz

That is, he is a binger. Alcohol theme.

theme
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
Malformed

Ilya’s ugly visage and disabilities are constantly highlighted in the text.

character
For instance, the game warden, Manul, who used to go after his fastidious needs to the Other Places, reported he had met there monstrosities even more atrocious.

This scene is revisited in chapter 4 (R176/E47).

intratextuality
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

character intratextuality motif
Other Places

Generally abroad, in other countries. The use of the capital letters also suggests a more metaphysical location, the other side of the river, the opposition between life and death.

foreign location explanatory theme
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
rasp

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

foreign
loaded

Drunk. Alcohol theme.

theme
Sloboda

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

location Russia setting
the dusk keeps whirlin above my foolish bean

Twilight will be Ilya’s downfall when he mistakes Yakov’s dog for a wolf. Here, it whirls above and, in a sense, becomes entwined with his head. Again, Ilya stresses his simplicity and modesty, defining his head as “stupid.”

character theme
Sharpenhauers

A reference to A. Sharpenhauer near the beginning of this chapter. Metonymy: his companions at the artel.

intratextuality intertextuality
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality motif
wild bender

Alcohol theme.

theme
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality motif
Malokulebyakovo

A town on the banks of the river.

setting location
kulebyako

Сoulibiac (кулебяка, kulebiaka): a Russian pie pastry (pirog) typically filled with salmon or sturgeon, rice or buckwheat, hard-boiled eggs, mushrooms, onions, and dill.

Russia
Kulebyako

Сoulibiac (кулебяка, kulebiaka): a Russian pie pastry (pirog) typically filled with salmon or sturgeon, rice or buckwheat, hard-boiled eggs, mushrooms, onions, and dill.

Russia
Kulebyakovo

The workmen split up the name of the town when answering Gury’s question and from here, it loses part of its name (malo means few in Russian). An example of incorrect segmentation characteristic for illiterate people.

location language
miller

Miller, related to the term мельница (mill, melnitsa), playing on the connection between “milling” and “pastries.” Sokolov will use the connection between torment (мука)/flour (мука) several times throughout the novel as well.

metaphor intratextuality character
miller’s

Miller, related to the term мельница (mill, melnitsa), playing on the connection between “milling” and “pastries.” Sokolov will use the connection between torment (мука)/flour (мука) several times throughout the novel as well.

metaphor character intratextuality
Chink

Derogatory slur referring to a person from Asia. The original Russian uses a slur referring to a person from the Caucasus or Central Asia.

translation register/style
Aladdin

Mentioned four times in the novel with different surnames (R153/E7, R199/E89, R242/E161, R278/E225). The name of Arabic origin Aladdin (Al al-Din) means “nobility of faith” and was popularized by the success of One Thousand and One Nights, before the 1992 homonymous Disney movie. Here it is used to suggest the Tatar origin of the character (directly indicated in Note XIV). His last name is mentioned alternatively as Batrutdinov and Rakhmatullin: the first derives from the Arabic name Batrutdin which means “full moon of the faith”; the second is a Tatar or Bashkir last name, derived from the name Rahmatullah, “mercy of God.”

character intratextuality intertextuality religion
Kulebyako

Сoulibiac (кулебяка, kulebiaka): a Russian pie pastry (pirog) typically filled with salmon or sturgeon, rice or buckwheat, hard-boiled eggs, mushrooms, onions, and dill.

Russia
Kulebyakovo

The town has lost the beginning of its name: Мало (Malo).

location setting language
rumors

Much of the novel, of course, involves rumors and gossip, mixing up stories and potential realities.

explanatory structure
fell into a dry well

Sokolov explains: “This is an ordinary village well with a windlass. The bucket is lowered and lifted with the aid of a windlass and a rope wrapped around it. From time to time in some village someone falls into the well wanting to draw water. Sometimes a child, sometimes a drunken adult. Sometimes a dog or a cat. If there is water in the well, the victim drowns. But if the well is dry, there is a chance that sooner or later the person or animal will be pulled out. They will if people hear screams or meows for help. It is impossible to get out of the well by yourself. The huntsman Ilya tells us about most likely fell into the well, as they say, because he was drunk, and his wife hastened to take advantage of this circumstance. There is nothing allegorical in the fall of the huntsman into the well” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

explanatory Russia
wife

Original Russian: супруга (supruga). Spouse. Officialese.

translation register/style
Ploski

A village in the Tver’ oblast. Ostanin provides several extensive lists explaining the novel’s geography and topography, which, like so much else in the novel, doesn’t always match up (17).

location Russia
Nikolay

A Nikolai different from Nikolai the Helper, introduced above. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
who never had his own name

Characters’ identities are constantly in flux.

explanatory character structure
Nikolay the Helper

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
transfiguration

Death. The reference is to the biblical Transfiguration of Jesus, in which Jesus goes to a mountaintop to pray with James, John, and Mark. Once there, he begins to shine with light, and Elijah (one of Ilya’s identities in the novel) and Moses appear beside him as the voice of God calls out to him. The event is documented in Matthew 17:1–8, Mark 9:2–8, and Luke 9:28–36. Celebrated on August 6. The main character of Mikhail Bulgakov’s Heart of a Dog (a novel which widely circulated in samizdat in the 60s) is Doctor Preobrazhensky, whose experiment of turning a homeless dog into a man leads to tragic consequences (and to his “transfigurating” back into a dog). Locally, this concept and its relationship to death also figures prominently in Note XVIII (R204–205/E95–96).

explanatory language intertextuality intratextuality bible religion theme
this one snatched his name for himself

Another theft.

theme
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality motif
Gury

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality motif
Whose

God’s.

religion
Nikola

Nikolai’s name shortens to Nikola. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Nikolka/Kolya.
