Ilya references the same song in chapter 6 (R190/E72-73). “Терем” refers to a tower-room, that is, living quarters in the topmost part of a building shaped like a tower. Common in ancient Rus’:

explanatory intertextuality Russia intratextuality music
tall tower

A tower-room, that is, living quarters in the topmost part of a building shaped like a tower. Common in ancient Rus’:.

Russia
couplers

Workers who couple train cars. Railroad theme.

explanatory theme
if someone was not allowed into the tall tower—it was none else but you, my dear.

A replay of the nineteenth-century song “Otrada” (“Joy”) with lyrics by Sergei Ryskin and music by Mikhail Shishkin. The song describes the singer’s love for a woman who is locked away in a high tower, echoing Orina’s displacement from Ilya. Listen here. Ilya references the same song in chapter 6 (R190/E72-73).

intertextuality music
Orya

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

intertextuality intratextuality theme character
unmown ditches

An allusion to the first line of Aleksandr Blok’s poem “On the Railroad” (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 234). Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s poem share thematic resonances: love, railroad, a mysterious woman, lost youth. Railroad theme.

intertextuality theme
hair pick

A key image in Ilya and Orina’s relationship. He gives it to her, and she lies about losing it on the train tracks. Introduced in chapter 1 (R156/E12). Comb motif.

motif intratextuality
cot

A reference to bunks or sleeping spaces on ships. Ilya will come into conflict with sailors who also pursue Orina. Boat motif.

explanatory motif intratextuality
I don’t have to hurry nowhere no more

According to Ostanin, a reference to Nikolai Alexandrovich von Ritter’s romance “Coachman, Don’t Drive the Horses” (1914), another tragic love song. Read the lyrics (in Russian) here, and listen to a recording here.

intertextuality music
hair pick

A key image in Ilya and Orina’s relationship. He gives it to her, and she lies about losing it on the train tracks. Introduced in chapter 1 (R156/E12). Comb motif.

motif intratextuality
Ascension

The Ascension of Christ to Heaven described in Luke 24:51. Celebrated on September 27 (14).

religion bible intertextuality time
leaf-slayer

A strong fall wind. From лист (leaf) and бой (fight).

language time
footwear

Ilya, of course, is missing a leg.

explanatory character
hair pick

A key image in Ilya and Orina’s relationship. He gives it to her, and she lies about losing it on the train tracks. Introduced in chapter 1 (R156/E12). Comb motif.

motif
Oryushka

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

intertextuality intratextuality character theme
hair pick

A key image in Ilya and Orina’s relationship. He gives it to her, and she lies about losing it on the train tracks. Introduced in chapter 1 (R156/E12). Comb motif.

motif
tongue

The male and female characters are constantly tempting one another. They are furthermore associated with animal and bodily imagery that frequently intertwined. An ambiguity: language vs. tongue. Orina uses her words (language) to calm Ilya down, but “tongue” also generates yet another animal-human connection. Animal-human motif.

explanatory motif language
hair pick

A key image in Ilya and Orina’s relationship. He gives it to her, and she lies about losing it on the train tracks. Introduced in chapter 1 (R156/E12). Comb motif.

motif
And the dawn, I note in passin, is breakin in the window and in the mirror, turnin into a first-class iridescent azure, and Orina’s downrite bathin there, supplethal, she’s splashin, exactly like in our promised pond in devil knows which summer, roughly in the month of July. Those days we haven’t yet shared affections, she kept deceivin, postponin— later and later—and I kept waitin and bearin it, encouraged

Natalya Fedotova and Daniil Osipov write: “This fragment presents a description in a fundamentally different color scheme (iridescent azure), opposed to the grayness of the narrator’s being. The hero is so ingrained in his perception of the everyday world, presented only in colors corresponding to the time of twilight (faded, faded, ash-gray, gray, grayish, ashy, ashy, the colors of unpainted felt, the colors of felt, the colors of crows and magpies), that the unreal, the realm of reveries, dreams are perceived by him as a colored dream, where the colors indistinguishable, but striking” (65–66).

explanatory
dawn

The dawn, as opposed to the twilight, when things become somewhat clearer.

time
Orina’s

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
supplethal

A neologism that blends supple (elastic, limber) and lethal (to perish, to die). Orina, and her alternative identity as the Dame, is frequently associated with death.

neologism language character theme
in devil knows which summer

In an unknown year, approximately in July.

time
shared affections

An allusion to sex.

theme
And two empty cable reels floated there, swellin, like at many other reservoirs

Sokolov explains: “Cable reel is shaped like a reel of thread, except that it is much larger, about one and a half to two meters in diameter. An empty reel, without cable, can serve as a round table in the garden. Having used the cable, electricians leave empty reels in the bosom of nature, and the boys play with them, in particular - roll them into the river or pond and float on them, since they are made of wood. Then the reels stay floating in those water reservoirs and get more and more swollen, soaking up in water. Ilya makes a mistake, perhaps deliberately: as in many other water reservoir (singular), while he should say: in many other water reservoirs (plural)” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

explanatory
bush of stag-head

This type of willow is often mentioned in Russian folklore. According to the myth, it grew on the very first rock on Earth, which was thrown out of the sea by a fish. Birds and animals living on this bush boast magic powers and can foresee the future. In literature, we find it in Nekrasov’s Who is Happy in Russia? (3rd part, ch. 5): the heroine laments her bitter fate while sitting on this bush. Read the original here and its English translation here. Plant motif. This bush will be mentioned again in chapter 14. Plant motif.

folklore motif intertextuality
shameless

Naked.

explanatory
I got plugged up with the shoe cord; the threaded tape tightened like a noose. There’s no way to break it, I was dealt a stubborn specimen. In short, I undid that knot with my teeth: They were still present

Ilya’s struggle with his footwear echoes that of Cinderella. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality symbol motif
teeth

An echo of the hairpins that Orina holds in her teeth a few lines above. More animal-like behavior from Ilya. Animal-human motif.

intratextuality motif
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
pearls

Orina will be compared to something white and shiny below. Ilya gathers mussels from the river. Animal motif.

symbol motif character
mutilation

Ilya’s accident on the train tracks that led to his lost leg. There is a recurrent theme of kaleki (disabled beggars) in Sokolov’s work. Railroad theme.

theme explanatory self-reference
casual joys

Other women.

explanatory
Orina’s

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
singin a stanza from one wonderful aria

Songs and singing are a recurring element in the novel.

music
You do look pretty, say, in any dress, but when you’re naked you look best

Boguslawski cites this line as a borrowing from the song “Luchshee plat’e — tvoia nagota” (“Your best dress is your nakedness”), author unknown (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 234). Fazil Iskander wrote the lyrics. Listen to a recording here. Read the complete poem (in Russian) here.

intertextuality music
It would have been better, however, if I had been less of a songbird in love, and more looked ahead

Natalya Fedotova and Daniil Osipov suggest that Sokolov uses “prospection as a form of temporary discountinuum that stops the linear unfolding of the novel’s plot” in order to “create an alternative reality, an oneiric space of the heroes’ dreams of another version of the unfolding events” (62). This use of time is contrasted with retrospection and cyclical time, two other key temporal modes of the novel (62).

time
songbird

One more bird reference (not by chance, after a song). The word echoes “перепало” a few lines above. Animal motif.

motif intratextuality
knot

Ilya’s struggle with his footwear echoes that of Cinderella. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality symbol motif
knot

Here: a railway junction. The knot on Ilya’s footwear becomes the site of his accident and misfortune with Orina. Railroad theme.

explanatory theme intratextuality
semafors

Mispelling: semaphores. A railroad signal post/light used to convey messages from a distance. An “apparatus for signalling.” From the Greek sema (sign, signal) and phoros (bearer). Used to transmit signals over a distance as for railway traffic. Orina works at a railway station. The railway is a key motif in Sokolov’s art.

theme self-reference explanatory
The first knot—thanks to the flashes of summer lightnin—I managed to untie, but the sortin one—even if all the nights there are full of fire

An allusion to the prison song “Taganka.” The title refers to the Taganka Prison in Moscow, which housed numerous political prisoners in both tsarist and Soviet times. The lights were never turned off in the prison, hence the line “полные огня” (“full of fire”). The prison was demolished in 1960. Read the lyrics here. Listen to a recording here. Early in this chapter, Ilya mentioned that he has not spent time in prisons despite his wanderings and his experience with large cities.

intertextuality music
lightnin

Ilya is frequently compared—by the narrator and by himself—to the prophet Ilya/Elijah, who is commonly associated with lightning and thunder.

intertextuality religion bible
unfatomable

Misspelling: unfathomable

language explanatory
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
white and shiny

Orina was described as wearing nothing but pearls above. Ilya gathers mussels from the river. Animal motif. Clothing motif.

explanatory character motif
saber

It is significant that Orina is associated with a long knife.

character symbol
all in all it was bearable, but I remember for me personally it was unbearable

Alexander Boguslawski notes that variations on this word are used in four key moments in the novel (R155, 157, 225, 254/E12, 14–15, 132, 185) and that the “close parallels between the first and last use of the phrase should be noted — this is the frame within which two other versions of the expression exist. These two framing elements are built around the word nevterpezh, a colloquial adverb, usually used after a noun or pronoun in dative case and often with auxiliary verbs to be or to become. Thus, the expression “mne stalo nevterpezh” [it became unbearable to me; I could not stand it any longer], [sic] is common. However, Sokolov makes some important alterations to the expression — first, he discards the dative government and substitutes another verb for the auxiliary” (“How Sokolov’s” 218).

language intratextuality
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
irrepressible spider

One more association of Ilya with an animal. Animal-human motif.

motif character
tincture

Refers to an infusion or tincture, but also a strong alcoholic drink — yet another instance of the alcohol theme in the novel.

theme explanatory
Orina

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
eyelids

Ilya uses the same word in chapter 6: “Roll up your eyelids like a pant leg, bare your stump, too” (R190/E73).

intratextuality
willows

A reference to the Неопалимая купина (Burning Bush) in the original. According to the Book of Exodus, Moses was given his charge to lead the Israelites out of Egypt at the Burning Bush. Plant motif.

intertextuality religion bible motif
crucians

Fish belonging to the Carassius genus and Cyprinidae family. Animal motif. This same question, and this scene in general, is repeated in chapter 8 by Ilya (R210/E106). Alexander Boguslawski notes: “Sokolov increases the artistic impact of these two descriptions by combining images with skillful manipulation of the lexical material. It is easy to see the delicate modulations of the phrase about the carp, achieved by synonymic substitutions prishchurilsia – prigliadelsia and dremali – kemarli as well as by replacement of zdes’ gde by tut u nas and of ershi eti samye by mne vzbrelo vdrug” (“How Sokolov’s” 215).

motif intratextuality
snails

Snail. Animal motif.

motif
mussels

The mussels alluded to above via the pearls: Also seen in chapter 8 (R207/E100). Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

explanatory intratextuality motif bible religion
Knockin around the world on account of my services

Ilya is an itinerant knife-grinder.

explanatory
lonely acordeon

Ostanin has identified this phrase as a borrowing from the 1945 drinking song “The Lonely Button Accordion” (“Одинокая гармонь”) by Mikhail Isakovsky. The song tells the story of a wandering accordion player who keeps girls awak at night with his music. One of the lines, “young accordion player” (гармонист молодой) echoes Between Dog and Wolf’s second epigraph: “The young man was a hunter” (Молодой человек был охотник). Read the lyrics (in Russian) here. Listen to a recording here.

intertextuality music
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location setting foreign language
deaf

Both the person and the place are defined as “deaf” (in the second case meaning “unknown” or “little known”).

language
filharmonic

Ilya’s music. His words, his performances, his music are lost on those in this region. He is out of place.

music explanatory
dull

Can also be used to describe a sound.

explanatory music
cuts

lya is describing a place where people don’t bother sharpening any of their blades, but the implication is yet another lack of understanding.

language explanatory
laziness

Often people and places in the novel are described as lazy.

intratextuality
dull

Can also be used to describe a sound.

music explanatory
borscht

A very popular soup in Eastern Europe, most commonly made from beets, which gives it its traditional vibrant red color. Originally from Ukraine.

foreign
hobble

Ilya limps because he is missing a leg. Several explanations for this disability are given throughout the novel, but the exact cause is never resolved.

explanatory character
Bydogoshch

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

location symbol theme foreign
cemetery

Yakov describes some of the “residents” of the cemetery in Note XXXI (R267–269/E207–210).

intratextuality location setting
Crystal Goose

From the town of Gus-Khrustalny, whose name could be translated as “crystal goose”: it is one of the oldest centers of glass industry in Russia and it stands on the Gus River.

Russia location
blue hooch

Raw vodka. Alcohol theme.

theme
dried-out eyes

A little dry, metaphorically looking for a drink. Alcohol theme.

theme explanatory
sarafan’s

Sarafan: a long dress worn in Russia. A key aspect of traditional folk culture. Clothing motif.

Russia motif folklore
ruche

A ruche — a frill, ruffle, pleat on clothing. Clothing motif.

motif
mother-in-law’s tongue

Mother-in-law’s tongue is a flowering plant (sansevieria) native to Africa and southern Asia, but also popular as a houseplant. The plant, as the name suggests, is linked with superstitions according to which it would badly affect the future of couples and families. Plant motif.

motif symbol
What and what—such an annoyin whatter

Sokolov has written about his desire to avoid the “what” in literature,” opting for the “how”: “In the milieu from which I come […] the traditions of so-called art-for-art’s sake are still alive. I am using here the expression so-called because by definition art is always for its own sake […] Forgive me for being so insistent, but art should be beautiful. And prose – should be refined and superior like poetry. […] Show me your how – a pass to truth, and take away what; I will find what myself.” (Sokolov, “The Key Word of Belles-Lettres,” In the House of the Hanged, 28-29).

self-reference
whatter

A person always and annoyingly asking “what?”

neologism
Wolf River

The Wolf River is alternatively called Itil’ and Volga in the novel.

location intratextuality
tramp

Ilya as itinerant knife-grinder.

explanatory
mussels

The mussels alluded to above. A sexual symbol in the novel (R158/E16). Associated with Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

motif religion bible intratextuality
I enjoy their taste

An echo of “Do they taste good?” above.

intratextuality
Ilyusha

Diminutive of Ilya. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character folklore intertextuality
Gorodnishchi

Another spelling of Gorodnishche. The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting intertextuality theme folklore
mussels

The mussels alluded to above. A sexual symbol in the novel (R158/E16). Associated with Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

motif religion intratextuality bible
And the stone—if you want

Natalya Fedotova and Daniil Osipov argue that Sokolov’s anthropomorphizing of the river plays with the folkloric motif of “living” and “dead” water (64).

intertextuality folklore
if you want, on your neck, and then keep restin to your health even to the Lastest Judgment

Ilya’s conversation with the river here is continued in chapter 4 (R176/E47-48). There, the “Lastest Judgment” becomes “the latter case.” The threat of death and the pull of suicide looms over Ilya and many of the men living on the banks of the Volga. However, as Martina Napolitano explains, “As if to exorcise it, as if to disavow it as incompatible with the characters’ very personal idea of a-chronological, nonlinear, circular and modifiable time, death is always spoken of in a metaphorical key” (“‘Studyin This Volapuke’” 287). Death is one of Sokolov’s central themes. As he put it in an interview with Olga Matich, “In that sense, I’m apparently traditional. I write on eternal themes: love, life, death. Death is inseparable from life. It’s constantly near, around us, in the objects that surround us. It becomes clearer in certain of its forms. For example, in old photographs. Since I was a child I’ve had a thought: everyone in photos from the previous century, at the very least those born in its first half, died. This fact particularly stands out when you look at group photos, at snapshots of massive street scenes. Or when you’re simply walking down the street at rush hour and suddenly see a freeze frame. All movement, the entire crowd momentarily stops, and you suddenly remember: in 60-70 years all of them will no longer be. Yourself included” (“Nuzhno zabyt’” 12). This fascination with death dates back to his childhood: “Visiting cemeteries […] was for me something like a home education. I was also interested in the theme of death. It’s, after all, the most interesting thing in life” (Kochetkova).

theme intratextuality structure self-reference
Lastest Judgment

Instead of Last Judgement (Doomsday), the River—as reported by Ilya—calls it “Lastest.” Again, the novel touches upon the theme of death.

language theme explanatory
Месяц ясен

This expression hides a double meaning, as the word “mesiats” may mean both “moon” and “month”. The author is at once suggesting that “the month is clear” (a rather indeterminate time setting) and that “the moon shines”. The formulation recalls also Nikolai Gogol’s Diary of a Madman (1834): “I don’t remember the date. There was also no month” (Ostanin 10). Finally, this opening sets up the novel’s fixation on seasonal time markers, as opposed to those created by humans.

Данное выражение скрывает в себя по крайней мере два значения: подразумевается либо месяц календаря, либо фаза луны. В первом случае это довольно неопределенное указание на время года, а во втором случае описывается, как луна сияет на небе. Формулировка напоминает “Записки сумасшедшего” Н. Гоголя: “Числа не помню. Месяца тоже не было” (Останин 10). К тому же, такое начало книги подсказывает, что в романе время движется согласно природным знакам времен года, оно не измеряется человеческими инструментами, приборами.

explanatory pun intertextuality time
Месяц ясен, за числами не уследишь, год нынешний

Elena Kravchenko writes: “Sokolov differs from both the avant-garde aestheticization of the real and the conceptualist disclosure of the hyper-real. Firstly, reality is a priori presented in a reflected form through a series of artistic representations. Secondly, in his engagement with these signs, Sokolov does not simply abstract them from their ‘original’ function or context, but grounds them in their original medium: language. […]. A pun, produced through a play on the homonym ‘mesiats’, throws off the reader, forcing him to reflect on the plurality of signifieds covered by a single name. By using the adjective ‘iasnyi’ (clear), with its indication of both clarity as colour and a level of intelligibility, the narrator provokes a double entendre, thus revealing the basis of the notion of time: the abstract category of time is grounded in a spatial (alberit heavenly) body” (The Prose 71).

language
Месяц ясен, за числами не уследишь, год нынешний. Гражданину Сидор Фомичу Пожилых с уважением Зынзырэлы Ильи Петрикеича — Заитильщина

Alexey Salomatin and Artem Skvortsov identify this opening line as a reference to the apocryphal “Correspondence between the Turkish Sultan and the Cossacks” (248). Read the original letter here. They note that the novel’s opening begins with a reference to the letter’s ending.

intertextuality
за числами не уследишь

Typical sample of Sokolov’s non-linear conception of time. See, for instance, Borden’s “Time Backward!” and Sokolov’s School for Fools and Palisandria.

Классический пример нелинеарного восприятия времени (см., например, R.C. Borden, Time, backward!: Sasha Sokolov and Valentin Kataev, и Школа для дураков и Палисандрия Соколова)

time self-reference intertextuality
год нынешний

This expression introduces the reader into a blurred atmosphere of uncertainty, where exact coordinates in space and time are deliberately foggy.

Данное выражение вводит читателя в мутную атмосферу неопределенности: пространственно-временные представления являются нарочито туманными.

explanatory time
Гражданину

Interestingly enough, Sokolov avoids using the most common Soviet appellative “Tovarishch” opting for a rather general, but still evocative word (think of Nikolay Nekrasov’s “Poet i grazhdanin,” Poet and Citizen, 1856). The choice could be also related to the epistolary genre Ilya is here trying to reproduce and to the fact that this world is rather the ‘old’ term substituting the Soviet “Tovarishch.”

Интересно заметить, что Соколов избегает употреблять советское слово “товарищ”, предпочитая ему более общий, зато значимый термин “гражданин” (ср. “Поэт и гражданин” Николая Некрасова, 1856). Выбор может еще и подсказывать, что Илья намерен “правильно” писать заявление и думает выражениями, типичными для “старого” (несоветского или, лучше, досоветского) времени.

register/style language
Сидор Фомичу

Sidor (shortened form of Isidor), son of Foma. Here the declension of the name is incorrect (should be in the dative case, Sidoru). In colloquial language, the names are sometimes declined incorrectly for easier pronunciation: Сан Санычу (San Sanychu), Михал Валерьичу (Mikhal Valer’ichu), etc. The name Isidor (or Sidor) originally means “son or gift of Isis,” the major goddess in ancient Egyptian religion, an ideal of femininity and motherhood who was also believed to help the dead enter the afterlife.

Сидор (сокращенная форма имени Исидор), сын Фомы. Здесь ошибка в склонении имени: правильная форма — Сидору (дательный падеж). В разговорной речи, имена иногда склоняются не совсем верно для более удобного произношения: Сан Санычу, Михал Валерьичу, и т. п. Имя Исидор (или Сидор) означает “сын или дар Исиды”, одной из главных богинь в древнеегипетской мифологии, идеала женственности и материнства, которая покровительствовала мертвым в загробной жизни.

character register/style
Пожилых

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character intertextuality
с уважением Зынзырэлы

E. Iablokov suggests that the connection to Cinderella in Ilya’s surname, as well as his social status, mark his as a typical “little person” (маленький человек) of Russian literature (205). In particular, he mentions the hero of Fyodor Dostoevsky’s epistolary novel Poor Folk, Makar Devushkin.

intertextuality
Зынзырэлы

Again an unusual last name (which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book). It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker’s essay, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356). However, as Korovashko suggests, “Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella ‘squared’: if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence” (277).

Еще одна необычная фамилия (которая встречается и в других графических-орфографических вариантов дальше в тексте). Намекается на сказку Золушки (по-английски Cinderella; cм. L. Toker, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356). Однако, Коровашко замечает, что “Илья Петрикеич становится как бы Золушкой «в квадрате»: если последняя потеряла всего лишь свой башмачок, то он утратил и ногу, и компенсирующие ее отсутствие костыли” (277).

character intertextuality
Ильи

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character folklore intertextuality
Петрикеича

Petrikeich is Ilya’s patronymic (“son of Petrik,” although this first name is not common). D.B. Johnson has noted that the patronymic contains an allusion to the folkloric figure of the “lisa Patrikeevna,” a trickster fox present in Slavic culture (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211). The reference to a fox is not by chance: Ilya will be transfigured into a fox in Orina’s imagination when tied to a railroad (she had brought the hide of her pet fox to a shoemaker who later took advantage of her). Animal motif.

character motif intertextuality intratextuality folklore
Заитильщина

The title that Ilya gives to his missive to Pozhilykh. Its name echoes that of the Zadonschina, a Russian manuscript of late 14th century, about the Battle of Kulikovo (1380) between Russians and Mongols. The contents of Ilya’s letters concern the events related to his life and death that occur “beyond the Itil River.” In this way, the story Ilya tells Pozhilykh becomes a real epic poem.

intertextuality
Разрешите уже, приступаю

Imitation of oral speech, which contradicts the written form of the “letter.”

register/style structure
Разрешите уже, приступаю

An3.

Ан3.

metrical pattern
Разрешите уже, приступаю. Гражданин Пожилых. Человек я для данных мест сравнительно посторонний

The original Ardis publication of the novel and several earlier editions read differently: “Разрешите уже, приступаю. Гражданин Пожилых. Я, хоть Вы меня, вероятно, и не признаете, гражданин, тоже самое, пожилой и для данных мест сравнительно посторонний.” Sokolov has made minor changes to the novel over the years.

explanatory edition
Гражданин Пожилых

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
Пожилых

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character structure religion
для данных мест

Again a blurred reference to the spatial dimension.

Еще одно неопределенное указание на контекст действия.

setting
сравнительно посторонний

A slight contradiction in semantics (how can one be only “relatively” an outsider?). Everything is relative in the novel: time, place, identity.

character language structure
но поскольку точильщик, постольку точу ножи-ножницы

An5GD.

Ан5ГД.

metrical pattern
поскольку точильщик, постольку точу ножи-ножницы

An example of Ilya’s overly complex language in which he often explains things by means of their own definitions.

Пример неоправданно усложненной манеры речи Ильи, в которой он часто объясняет вещи их же собственными определениями.

language
с панталыку меня вряд ли, пожалуй, сбить

Set expression (“s pantalyku sbit’”): to confuse somebody.

Устойчивое выражение: запутать, привести в замешательство

phraseologism
с первого взгляда

An unusual usage of the expression in this context (“a gimp at first sight”).

Необычное употребление выражения в контексте (“культяп с первого взгляда”).

phraseologism
культяп

Colloquial: gimp, stump. See also Bruegel’s painting The Beggars (1568): Beggars touches on a number of Sokolovian themes: deformities and handicaps, dancing, inversions of social order. It likewise features the fox imagery of Between Dog and Wolf. Manfred Sellink writes, “these paupers are performing (or rather trying to perform) a dance. The man in the centre, looking out at us, has straps with bells around his legs. The faces that can be seen have their mouths open, as it they are singing. The cripples are all dressed up, their white garments with foxtails mockingly evoking […] the expensive ermine robes worn by the most rich and powerful. This suggestion is strengthened by their equally evident headdresses, mimicking those on the heads of the mighty: a mitre, a crown and a fur cap. Given the fact that Bruegel is working here on a motif from his earlier Carnival painting, the painting touches on one of the essential aspects of Carnival festivities - a moment that briefly reverses the normal social order and class distinctions […] The appearance of the foxtails in conjunction with beggars in two totally different paintings, one dating from 1559 and the other from 1568, suggests that here the attribute is associated with popular customs, possibly connected with Carnival and Shrove Tuesday. There were longstanding traditions in which foxtails were seen as symbols of foolishness and deceit” (283).

register/style intertextuality foreign
Точу и косы, и топоры, и другой хозтовар

Ya2 + Dak4M.

Я2 + Дак4М.

metrical pattern
косы

Braid, scythe, or sandback/spit. The ambiguity of the word “kosa” has a famous literary “predecessor” in Aleksandr Blok’s drama Balaganchik (The Puppet Show, 1906). The female character of Columbine has a “kosa” behind her back: either a hair braid or a scythe. The “mystics” warn Pierrot about her being Death, but he calls her his bride (“Я не слушаю сказок. Я — простой человек. Вы не обманете меня. Это — Коломбина. Это — моя невеста”; I don’t listen to fairy tales. I am a simple man. You will not deceive me. This is Columbine. This is my bride). The ambiguity is also stressed by the character of the Author who enters the scene and exclaims: “Я не признаю […] аллегорической игры словами: неприлично называть косой смерти женскую косу! Это порочит дамское сословие!” (I do not recognize […] such allegorical wordplay: it is indecent to call a woman’s braid a scythe of death! It denigrates a lady’s status!). In the end, Pierrot sadly discovers that this Columbine was just a “cardboard bride” (Она картонной невестой была). The crucial theme linking a woman’s love to death draws parallels between Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s Balaganchik, although there is a very long literary tradition that has developed this line (e.g., Eros and Thanatos; Catullus’s Odi et amo, I hate and I love). Read the original by Blok here.

intertextuality theme language
хозтовар

A shortened form of хозяйственный товар (household goods).

Сокращенная форма словосочетания “хозяйственный товар”.

language
усугубили бы речь

Unusual occurence of this verb (usually “usugubit’ situatsiiu”, “usugubit’ polozhenie del”)

Необычное употребление глагола “усугубить” (обычно усугубить ситуацию”, “усугубить положение дел”)

phraseologism
речь. По реченной причине

Alliteration (ch, n, rech, chen-chin).

Аллитерация (ч, н, речь, чен-чин).

sound stylistic device
реченной

Archaic word, echoing the “rech’” just mentioned.

archaism sound play
отзвонивших-и-с-колокольни-долой лет

Set expression: to get some business over with so as not to come back to it again.

phraseologism
до сего дня

Archaic form.

Архаизм.

archaism
в судимые не попал, даром что обитал в значительных городах

The narrator suggests that in big towns it is easier to have problems with the law and police.

Предполагается, что в больших городах легче иметь проблемы с законом и полицией.

explanatory
не попал, даром что обитал в значительных городах

Internal rhyme (popAl - obitAl - gorodAkh).

Внутренняя рифма (попал - обитал - городах).

rhyme
значительных городах

Large cities. Ilya is an itinerant knife-sharpener. The novel mostly takes place on the banks of the Itil (Volga) River, within a community of hunters, artisans, and invalids. Ilya has travelled and seen much.

Большие города. Илья — странствующий точильщик ножей. Действие романа происходит на берегах реки Итиль (Волги) в окружении охотников, ремесленников и инвалидов. Илья много где был и много чего видел.

location
Куковал

This verb both introduces the bird motif, associating characters with birds (and, more generally, animals), and suggests via its figurative meaning (“being forced to be somewhere”) the itinerant nature of Ilya. José Vergara suggests that Sokolov’s bird imagery “underscores the inherent tie between the characters (humanity) and nature in the novel. That is, the natural world in the guise of various animals does not only reflect the characters’ emotions and experiences.
