They may wish to overcome their status as beings of flesh, blood, and nature, but the bird imagery – among other things – constantly reminds them of their earthbound existence. They seek to escape the pull of the mundane and wearisome existence they live and to reach an ideal, but they are consistently dragged back down” (“Flap” 364).

Данный глагол и вводит “птичий мотив”, связывающую персонажей и птицами (или вообще животными), и образно подсказывает передвижной и странствующий характер Ильи. Хосе Вергара считает, что птичья тематика Соколова “подчеркивает присущую роману связь между персонажами (человечеством) и природой”. То есть мир природы в облике различных животных не только отражает эмоции и переживания персонажей. Они могут хотеть преодолеть свой статус существ из плоти, крови и природы, но образы птиц - помимо всего прочего - постоянно напоминают им об их земном существовании. Они стремятся освободиться от притяжения обыденного и утомительного существования, которым они живут, и достичь идеала, но их постоянно тянет обратно вниз” (“Flap” 364).

character motif
Куковал где поселят и запросто

An3.

Ан3.

metrical pattern
запросто

Colloquial: easily.

Разговорное слово.

register/style
се́мью понастоящему

Later on in the book the reader will understand why his family cannot be consider a real, authentic one.

Дальше в книге читатель узнает, почему семью Ильи нельзя считать полностью “настоящей”.

explanatory intratextuality character
болел

Ilya’s search for his family (his son, Yakov, and his wife, Orina in various forms), however, will be a major plot point in the novel.

Поиск Ильи своей семьи (сына, Якова, и жены, Орины в разных формах), однако, станет ключевым моментом в сюжете.

intratextuality character
публики

Ilya defines his clients as some “public,” as if his profession were closer to the arts (that of errant minstrels and the like) than to mere artisanry.

Илья называет свою клиентуру “публикой”, как если бы его дело больше напоминало бы искусство (подобно бродячим музыкантам), чем простое ремесло.

explanatory language character
вспомоществовать

Archaic, officialese: to help, aid.

Архаизм, канцелярское слово.

archaism register/style
по мере сил и возможностей

Set expression.

Устойчивое выражение.

phraseologism
В чем

Ambiguity: Is Ilya remorseful about his ways of providing for a living or about not having a family?

Неоднозначное употребление местоимения: он же раскаивается в том, как зарабатывает, или в отсутствии семьи?

explanatory language
раскаиваюсь

To repent. Religious undertones that align with the novel’s association of characters with various saints and other religious figures.

Религиозный подтекст, сочетающийся с часто проводимой в романе параллелью между героями и святыми или другими религиозными деятелями

language religion
этого

Again it is unclear whether the co-op represents a substitute for a job or for a “surrogate” family.

Неясно, является ли артель собститутом работы или семьи.

explanatory
артель

A workers or artists cooperative.

explanatory
артель индивидов

The workers’ cooperative (a joint venture) is in contrast with the “individuals” who work there. This pairing, in a sense, describes the novel’s use of “forking characters” who constantly shift names and identities. For this reason, Between Dog and Wolf has often, though too simplistically been called the “Russian Finnegans Wake. For example, Richard Borden writes, “Aside from its perceived inaccessibility, its extremely disjointed narrative, its profound elusiveness and allusiveness, the fundamental timelessness of its narrative, its seeming to operate more according to the laws of dream than of waking experience, its wealth of neologism and, in particular, of complex paronomasia, Between Dog and Wolf resembles Finnegans Wake in its forking characters, in the way characters seem to dissolve one into the other—or evolve one from the other” (“Toward” 389).

Объединение рабочих (совместное предприятие) противопоставляется работающим там “индивидам”. Подобное сочетание в каком-то смысле отождествляет “расходящихся (разветвляющихся) персонажей”, постоянно меняющих имена и личности.

language
индивидов

The word “individ” is bookish in Russian, and thus in this context it sounds unnaturally; the actual word Ilya possibly meant to use was “invalid.”

Книжное слово “индивид” не соответствует тону письма и догадывается, что на самом деле Илья имел в виду слово “инвалид”.

register/style
Д. Заточника

This name is linked with the Old East Slavic text “Praying (or Supplication) of Daniil Zatochnik” (13th century), addressed to the Prince of Pereyaslavl and Suzdal in order to receive help and grace. In addition to “sharpen,” the root verb in the name Zatochnik, zatochnit’, also means to “imprison” (so Daniil could have been an exiled man). Thus, there is an irony with what Ilya writes about never having been incarcerated. D. Zatochnik is echoed also in Sokolov’s A School for Fools, when the main character describes his fictional work at his father’s office as being a “pencil sharpener”: “Первое время мы служили в прокуратуре у отца, он взял нас к себе на должность точильщиков карандашей, и мы побывали на многих судебных заседаниях” (in English, the translation is slightly different: “At first we worked for our father in the prosecutor’s office; he hired us as filers of files and we were present at many court proceedings”) (E174/R143).

character self-reference irony intertextuality
контора

That same “artel’” (co-op).

То есть, та же артель.

explanatory location setting
В теплоту

When it is warm, in the warm months. By contrast, the following sentence explains what they do in the cold periods (“v morozy”, literally ‘in frosts’).

То есть, когда тепло, когда погода тепла.

explanatory time
вокруг да около

Describes a manner of speaking: beating around the bush, i.e., Ilya’s narrative.

Описывает манеру речи Ильи: не касаться сути.

language
около и отходим в отхожие

Alliteration (ok/otkh).

Аллитерация (ок/отх).

sound stylistic device
отходим в отхожие промысла́.

They find seasonal jobs.

Занимаются сезонной работой.

explanatory
промысла́

This word is incorrectly stressed, revealing that Ilya is semi-literate.

register/style
поелику

Archaic: because.

Устаревшее слово: поскольку.

archaism
бобыльё

Archaic/dialectal: a landless peasant.

Архаизм, диалектизм: безземельный крестьянин.

archaism
уроды

Compare to удод (hoopoe) on the last page of the novel, in Yakov’s final poem. Moreover, it is interesting to note that Ilya defines himself as a “monster,” an “ugly thing,” while the author of the Notes will in the end stress his confidence in his own talent.

В сравнении с “удодом” с последней страницы романа, в заключительной строфе Якова. Более того, интересно заметить, что Илья называет себя “уродом”, тогда как автор Записок в конце подчеркивает его уверенность в собственном таланте.

intratextuality
Вашенского

Mock imitation of high register (“Vashensky” instead of “vash”).

Имитация высокого стиля (вместо “вашего”).

register/style
звенят и крутятся на зеркале вод

They go ice-skating, the “mirror of the waters” being the frozen ice on the surface of rivers (a possible allusion to Pushkin’s “Oktyabr’”; see Ostanin 12). It may sound ironic given their physical disability.

Катаются на коньках (выражением “на зеркале вод” автор может быть ссылается на стихи Пушкина “Октябрь”; см. Останин 12). Иронично звучит, поскольку они же инвалиды.

explanatory intertextuality
как смеркнется

When it gets dark. Ilya is describing in detail how life goes in these villages by the Volga River, what people do over the course of the day and of the year.

Когда стемнеет. Илья подробно описывает жизнь в приволжьих деревнях, чем занимаются жители на протяжении дня/года.

explanatory Russia setting time character
тошниловке

Pejorative, colloquial: a drinking hole causing nausea (from the verb toshnit’). Gerald Smith appropriately calls Between Dog and Wolf “one of the most sustained and elaborated drinking songs in the whole of Russian literature” (“The Verse” 330). Alcohol theme.

register/style theme setting location
прозванной с чьей-то заезжей руки кубарэ; но Илью среди них не обрящете

Dak4 + An3. The cesura is highlighted thanks to the semicolon.

Дак4 + Ан3. Цезура подчеркивается точкой с запятой.

metrical pattern
с чьей-то заезжей руки

It stresses the foreign origin (and sound) of the word “kubare.”

Подчеркивается иноязычное происхождение (и следовательно чуждость звука) слова “кубарэ”.

explanatory foreign
кубарэ

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’,” informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin. On Sokolov’s use of neologisms, see Brainina.

foreign neologism setting location
Илью

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
обрящете

The use of this unusual verb suggests a direct quotation from the Bible: “seek and you will find” (Matthew 7:7). Sokolov himself stated that: “What did I really want at the beginning, so to speak, of my writing career? I thought there were great books. Someone says there are 30, someone says 40. I counted about 40. We studied all these books in the Journalism Department. Roughly the same list as in American universities. Some Moby Dick, Joyce. I always felt that in this list the best books were really missing—clearly the Bible, the New Testament. How much did the authors of the New Testament write? Somebody 20 pages, somebody else 40, and that’s it. That’s how much it takes to write” (Kochetkova).

Прямая ссылка на библейское выражение “Ищите и обрящете”, то есть “найдете” (От Матфея 7:7). Сам Соколов однажды утверждал: “Что мне вообще хотелось в начале, так сказать, моей писательской деятельности? Я думал, что есть великие книги, кто-то говорит, что их 30, кто-то говорит — 40. Я насчитал примерно 40. Мы все эти книги изучали на факультете журналистики. Примерно тот же список в американских университетах. Какой-нибудь «Моби Дик», Джойс. Но мне всегда казалось, что в этом списке отсутствуют действительно лучшие книги — это, конечно, Библия, Новый Завет. Авторы Нового Завета — сколько они написали? Вот кто-то написал 20 страниц, а кто-то 40 — и все. Вот так нужно писать” (Кочеткова).

intertextuality register/style bible self-reference
взгрустнется

Colloquial: to suddenly become sad.

Разговорное слово.

register/style
мымра

Disparaging/colloquial: gloomy.

Пренебрежительное/просторечное слово.

register/style
точеных

Ice skates (the same ellipsis is found further, “na ostrykh”).

Коньки (эллипсис встречается и дальше, “на острых”).

explanatory
как у людей

Set expression: as other people do.

Устойчивое выражение (обычно “всё как у людей”).

phraseologism
острых

Ice skates.

Коньки

explanatory
гладкому

The frozen river.

Замерзшая река.

explanatory
гребует

Dialectal: to disdain, abhor.

Диалектное слово.

register/style
да не отрекусь, и не из тех я точильщиков

Colloquial syntaxis.

Разговорный синтаксис.

register/style
востры

A connection between Ilya’s profession and his description of himself.

Проводится параллель между профессией Ильи и его описанием себя.

character
Пара, правда, нам ни к чему

Ilya is missing a leg, so he needs only one skate.

У Ильи недостаёт ноги, поэтому ему нужен только один конёк.

explanatory character
снегурок

A type of ice skates, usually for beginners. In this picture: Ivan Tolstoy’s (son of Lev Tolstoy) snegurki.

Коньки, обычно для начинающих. В картине: снегурки Вани Тольстого.

explanatory
на блезире

A reformulation of the archaic expression “dlya bleziru,” meaning for pleasure or for show.

“Для блезиру” - для забавы, для вида (устаревшее выражение).

phraseologism archaism
очутился

Colloquial: to wind up, to appear, to turn up.

Разговорное: появиться.

register/style
ущерблен

Archaic word: to be damaged. May also refer to the moon (see above).

Устаревшее: повреждён. Может относиться к луне (см. выше).

register/style archaism
кремнист

Flint-like, i.e., immobile because of his disability.

Похожий на кремень, т.е., малоподвижный в силу своей инвалидности.

explanatory
отпихнуться

Colloquial: to push off, categorically deny.

Разговорное слово.

register/style
дзынь

This word recalls, in its sound, Dzynzerela.

По звучанию напоминает слово “Дзынзырэла”.

sound play
разá

Stress should fall on the first syllable.

Неправильное ударение, должно быть рАза.

register/style
Пожилых

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character intertextuality religion
дзынь

This word recalls, in its sound, Dzynzerela.

По звучанию напоминает слово “Дзынзырэла”.

sound play intertextuality
раза

In the 2014 OGI edition the second ‘a’ is stressed, as above.

В издании 2014 года ударение, как и выше, поставлено на второй слог.

edition
брюзжи себе под дугою хоть до Валдай-пристани

Ostanin notes references to Mikhail Glinka’s “Dream of a Russian in a Foreign Land” (1825), Fyodor Dostoevsky’s Notes of a Writer (1877), and Andrei Bely’s “First Meeting” (1921) (Ostanin, 13).

Останин ссылается на “Сон русского на чужбине” (Ф. Глинка, 1825), “Дневник писателя” (Ф. Достоевский, 1877) и “Первое свидание” (А. Белый, 1921). (Останин, 13)

intertextuality music
Валдай

A town located in Novgorod Oblast first mentioned in a chronicle in 1495 and known for the manufacture of bells in eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Mentioned several times throughout the novel (R150, 155, 198, 230, 272/E2, 11, 87, 88, 140, 214).

Город в Новгородской области, впервые упоминается в летописи 1495 года. Известен литьём ямщицких колокольчиков в XVIII-XIX вв. Неоднократно упоминается в романе (R150, 155, 198, 230, 272/E2, 11, 87, 88, 140, 214).

location Russia intratextuality music setting
литье бубенчиков

Valdai is well-known for its bell manufacturing. Here, Ilya refers to small bells such as those used on horse-drawn sleighs. A buben is an instrument similar to the tambourine. The main difference is that some bubens have metal rings, plates, cymbals, or bells attached. Also mentioned at the end of chapter 2 (“некто нетрезво бьет в бубен” [R163/E25]) and in chapter 3 in one of Yakov’s poems (“Некто с бубном бредет пелесками” [R169/E35]).

Валдай известен литьем колоколов. Здесь Илья имеет в виду ямщицкие колокольчики. Изображено ниже: Бубен — инструмент, напоминающий тамбурин. Основное отличие от тамбурина заключается в том, что у бубнам обычно подвешены металлические кольца или колокольчики. Упоминается в главе 2 (“некто нетрезво бьет в бубен” [R163/E25]) и в главе 3, в одном из стихов Якова (“Некто с бубном бредет пелесками” [R169/E35]). Изображено ниже:

explanatory intratextuality music
Итилю

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location language foreign setting
продлить

Rather than write “to continue” (продолжить), Ilya writes “to extend” (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 32). This innocuous question gestures toward his desire to keep telling his story, avoiding death in the process.

Илья пишет “продлить” вместо “продолжить”. (Богуславский, “Аннотации” 32).

explanatory language theme
Декабря в четвертый четверг

December 24.

24 декабря.

time
Декабря в четвертый четверг, читай в Канун

According to E. Iablokov, this period of the year is traditionally known as “wolf season” (волчий сезон) and the Slavic name for December is влченец (волк – wolf) (206). Animal motif.

time motif
четвертый четверг, читай

Alliteration (chet/chit).

Аллитерация (чет/чит).

sound stylistic device
Канун

The day before a holiday: Christmas Eve.

Предпраздничный день: Сочельник.

explanatory time religion
из-за реки

Movement across the river Itil’/Lethe and the movement from the other side on the night before Christmas suggests the expectation of a new life.

location setting theme
погребальщика

Gury (see below).

Гурий (см. ниже).

character
Провожали

To see off (i.e., to bury).

В смысле “хоронить”.

phraseologism
одного одинокого

A continuation of the individual/collective theme.

Продолжение темы индивида/коллектива.

theme
одного одинокого

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

stylistic device sound
отбросившего коньки

Set expression: to die (literally, to kick off one’s skates). Here the phraseologism gets concrete and real (Gury kicked off his skates indeed).

Умер (устойчивое выражение). Этот фразеологизм воплощается в жизнь (Гурий действительно отбросил свои коньки).

explanatory phraseologism
Мыло — можно сказать — мукомолове

Mylomukomolovo, a tongue-twister (non-existent) toponym, that will appear in other chapters also with a slight different name: Milokurekemovo and Malokulelemovo. The paronomastic stress on the words mukà/mùka (flour and pain, according to the accent) will be repeated many times in the novel, underlining the closeness of the two concepts. See R218/E119.

location neologism intratextuality symbol
на отшибе

Colloquial: on the outskirts, in the periphery.

Разговорное выражение.

register/style
ужовниках

Adder’s-tongue, an ancient, primordial group of ferns. Plant motif.

Ophioglossāceae, древняя примитивная группа растений. Изображено ниже: Мотив растений.

motif
ветляка

White willow. Plant motif.

explanatory motif
был охотник

See also one of the epigraphs, “the young man was a hunter.”

См. “молодой человек был охотник” в эпиграфе.

intratextuality
бормотов, довольно-таки мохноногих

This expression mixes up an adjective used in general for birds (owls, in particular) with a verb denoting muttering, to which a reference to post correspondence (“perepiska”) adds up a new, final meaning: he presumably kept mail pigeons. Animal motif.

Это выражение сочетает одно прилагательное, связанное с птичьей темой, с глаголом “бормотать”; к нему же при этом добавляется понятие “переписки”, которое подсказывает, что речь скорее идет о голубиной почте. Мотив животных.

explanatory motif
сомневаюсь, чтоб состоял в переписке с кем-либо: сомнительно

Figura etymologica (I doubt, doubtfully).

Этимологическая фигура речи (сомневаюсь, сомнительно).

stylistic device sound
переписке

Ilya’s tale, of course, takes the form of a letter to Pozhilykh, and, close to the end of the novel, Yakov will recount reading other people’s mail with the local postman, Sila Silych, in Note XXVI (R238/E153).

Повесть Ильи имеет форму переписки с Пожилых, а в конце романа Яков вспонимает, как они с местным почтальоном Силой Силичем читали чужие письма, в Записке XXVI (R238/E153).

structure intratextuality
как то мочало в жары́

Similitude.

Сравнение.

register/style poetic device
а звали его — я не припомню как. Гурий — так и звали его, если на то пошло

Sokolov’s typical device of the “disconnection” among reality and names.

Характерный соколовский прием: несовпадение вещей и имен.

language
Гурий

Gury’s first appearance. Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intratextuality motif
Гурия

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means “little lion” (gur ‘aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian’s Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

intratextuality character intertextuality motif
пошаркать и раскатиться

Ilya’s interests above transferred to Gury.

Развлечение Ильи, упомянутое выше, переходит к Гурию.

explanatory character
точеных

Ice skates.

Коньки.

explanatory
мы клиента утратили, а погребальщики клиента же обрели

Gury fell into the ice on the Volga and drowned. Thus, the knife-grinders lost his business, but the undertakers took care of his remains.

explanatory theme
мы клиента утратили, а погребальщики клиента же обрели

Rhythm is stressed by the repetition of the same syntactical structure.

Ритм подчеркивается повторением той же синтаксической структуры.

rhythm
обрели

Literary: to gain, acquire.

Литературное: найти, отыскать, получить.

register/style
поставлю в известность

Officialese.

Канцелярский стиль.

register/style
стрелецкие числа,

Sagittarius (November 22 - December 21). As explained by Sokolov himself, “in the book stars and constellations play mainly an aesthetic role, or, if you will, a decorative role, and there is nothing symbolic to look for in them. The ‘Sagittarius dates’ are just days in November and December, when the cold weather is not so severe, and the ice on the river is thin: skating then is a dangerous business” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Знак зодиака (с 22 ноября по 21 декабря). Сам Соколов объясняет, что “звезды и созвездия в книге играют роль во многом эстетическую, или, если угодно, декоротативно-прикладную, ничего символического в них искать не надо. Стрелецкие числа - просто дни в ноябре и декабре, когда морозы не столь сильны и лед на реке тонок: катание на коньках тогда - дело опасное” (личная переписка, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory time
опасней

As will become clear, many of the characters feel a pull toward death and take unnecessary risks and challenges.

Как станет ясно, много персонажей испытывают тягу к смерти и идут на неоправданные риски.

explanatory theme
бодрей, бобыли обоих мелкоплесовских берегов обустраивают

Alliteration (b).

Аллитерация (б).

sound stylistic device
мелкоплесовских берегов

The two banks of the river between which the characters continually drift.

Два берега реки, между которыми скользят персонажи.

setting location
слабеющем льду

The skaters prefer to race in the dark without the aid of lights in order to make the game more thrilling. They attempt to avoid the holes and other dangers lurking on the surface of the frozen Volga River.

Повышенный риск.

explanatory
кромешной темени

As opposed to twilight — total darkness.

По сравнению с сумерками — полная темнота.

theme time
без небесных светил

Characters are often associated with constellations throughout the novel. Here, despite the races occurring under the watch of Sagittarius, there are is no starlight. Constellation-heavens motif.

На протяжении романа, персонажи нередко сравниваются с небесными созвездиями. Здесь же, несмотря на то, что состязания проводятся в период Стрельца, звёзд не видно.

motif
горелки

An old folk game (catch, stovetop), at the beginning of which participants traditionally sing “Burn, burn brightly, so that it does not go out” (Gori, gori yasno, chtoby ne pogaslo). Watch the game being played here. Read the lyrics here. This song will also appear in one of Yakov’s chapters (R252/E180).

Russia folklore music
взапуски

Colloquial: to overtake.

Разговорное слово.

register/style
чревовато

Neologism from “chrevato” (fraught) and “chrevo” (womb): a space that is fraught. The womb—a place of life—in opposition to the death that these skaters face.

Чрево (утроба) — место жизни — противопоставляется смерти, которую встречают конькобежцы.

neologism theme
Николай, паренек из утильной, в конечном итоге, артели. По фамильярному прозванью Угодник

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

religion intertextuality intratextuality character folklore
утиль

An echo of the Itil’ (Итиль) River.

Отголосок названия реки Итиль.

sound play language location
незадачник

Неудачник = failure, loser.

neologism
ехидствовали

Colloquial: to tease, make fun of.

Разговорное слово.

register/style
выдрючивается

Colloquial: to attract attention by any means.

Просторечное слово.

register/style
мыкаться

Colloquial: to wander, ramble, move back and forth.

Разговорное: беспорядочно, суетливо двигаться.

register/style
мол

Colloquial: he says.

Разговорное: говорит.

register/style
в обычину

Neologism from обычно (usually). Suggests that he does this regularly.

Неологизм от обычно. Регулярно.

neologism
невезухи

Colloquial: failures.

Разговорное: неудача.

register/style
изведал

High: to learn, come to understand, experience.

Высокий стиль: научиться, понять.

register/style
матату

Usually, the word “matata” is used only in the idiom “navodit’/navesti [razvodit’] matatu”: talk nonsense, mislead someone. Thanks to the presence of the verb “izvedat’” it is possible to understand that in this word converge both the meaning of the word ‘matata’, and the one of ‘mutota’ (slang), that is nonsense, rubbish.

Обычно, слово “матата” находится только в фразеологизме “наводить/Навести [разводить] матату” = говорить ерунду, вводить в заблуждение кого-либо. От того, что здесь есть глаголь “изведать” понимаем что, на семантику “мататы” добавилась семантика жаргонного слова “мутота” = чушь, дрянь.

phraseologism
поладила

Colloquial: to get along with, to hit it off with.

Разговорное: ужиться, найти общий язык.

register/style
волкобоем

Sokolov explains: “in the old days, a hunter who beat wolves from a horse with a brush” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “в старину охотник, бьющий Волков с лошади кистенем” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory language
сжила

Colloquial: to chase out.

Разговорное: выгнать

register/style
сжила Угодника долой со двора

Many of the characters are displaced from their homes, often more than once. They feel out of place in this area despite their community and their work. On one level, this theme speaks to Sokolov’s own self-exile when he took up a job as a game warden in the Upper Volga region and subsequently his exile from Soviet Russia. The novel is dedicated to “приятелям по рассеянью” — comrades in exile.

Множество героев вынуждены покинуть дом, зачастую, не один раз. Несмотря на общину и совместную работу, они чувствуют себя в этом месте чужими. С какой-то стороны, тема изгнания героев созвучна с самоизгнанием самого Соколова, когда он принял должность егеря в Верхневолжье, а позже — его изгнанием из Советской России. Роман также посвящен “приятелям по рассеянью”.

theme self-reference intratextuality character
Угодника

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
городнищенский

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

Главное место действия романа: вымышленный город на берегу Волги, также называется Городнищи. Название получено в результате сочетания слов “город” и “нищий”. Таким образом, Городнищи — город нищих. О. Матич пишет: “Если Школа для дураков была написана в противовес молодежной прозе, следующий роман Соколова, Между собакой и волком можно расценивать как ответ автора на деревенскую прозу, модное литературное направление семидесятых” (Matich “Sasha Sokolov” 310). В. Крейд замечает, что Городнище, барачный город нищих и воров, напоминает “Анти-Китеж” (Китеж — мифический город в русском фольклоре, в который попадают только чистые сердцем). В Городнище, однако, воры грабят нищих, и нищие попрошайничают у грабителей (Kreid “Zaitil’shchina” 213). Согласно Джонсону, Городнище — обитель живых, в то время как мертвые населяют противоположный берег реки, в Быдогощах (Johnson “Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Джонсон также цитирует самого Соколова: “Соколов замечает, что название города является помесью развратного города XVIII века Городни, описанного А. Н. Радищевым в Путешествии из Петербурга в Москву и близлежащего города Городище. Таким образом, временные слои XVI века, XVIII века и мифического настоящего накладываются друг на друга — типичный роману прием” (217).

location intertextuality folklore theme setting
от ворот поворот

Set expression: to show someone the door.

Устойчивое выражение.

phraseologism
от ворот поворот

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

stylistic device sound
глухарей
  1. Colloquial: deaf. 2. Wood grouse. Animal motif.
  1. Разговорное: глухой человек. 2. Вид птиц.
register/style motif
ты, как видишь, еще и слепак

Ironic oxymoron.

Ироничный оксиморон.

pun irony
посунулся

Colloquial: to move slightly to one side.

Разговорное: слегка переместиться в сторону.

register/style
фисгармоника

An accordion or harmonium. Ilya later refers to this instrument in chapter 6 (R191/E73). Throughout the novel, Ilya mixes up instrument vocabulary and refers to his accordion by various names.

Аккордеон или гармонь. Илья ссылается на этот инструмент в главе 6 (R191/E73). Изображен ниже:

intratextuality music
ошивался

Colloquial: to linger, to be around.

Разговорное слово.

register/style
дебаркадерам

A floating pier or railway platform. Both locations-images are relevant to the novel: the characters shuttle back and forth across the Volga River, and Ilya loses his leg to a train. In 1837 the first train appeared in the Russian Empire, connecting Tsarskoe Selo and St. Petersburg. Since then, trains and railroads have become an important theme in Russian literature, relevant still today. From the elite’s means of transportation (see the train scenes in Lev Tolstoy’s Anna Karenina, for example) to popular commutes (see Zoshchenko’s short story “A Pleasant Meeting,” Venedikt Yerofeev’s masterpiece Moscow to the End of the Line, or the recent book by Dmitry Danilov Empty Trains 2022), trains have represented an essential trait of everyday life. In Sokolov’s oeuvre trains and railroads occupy a key place, as D.B. Johnson convincingly demonstrated in his 1986 article “Sasha Sokolov’s Twilight Cosmos: Themes and Motifs”: the river and the railroad are the central themes in Sokolov’s literary world, as they connect all other themes (time, death, memory, and sex). Railroad theme.

Плавучая пристань или накрытая навесом часть железнодорожной платформы. Оба места-образа прямым образом относятся к роману: персонажи постоянно переправляются через Волгу, а Илья теряет ногу в аварии на железной дороге. Тема железной дороги.

setting theme location
Угодников Николай

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality folklore religion
во весь свой скрюченный рост

Ironic oxymoron.

Ироничный оксиморон.

pun irony
скрюченный

Colloquial: to double up, to bend.

Разговорное: согнутый.

register/style
бельмами

Low/rude: eyes. Also refers to a leukoma, an opaque or white spot found in the cornea.

Просторечное/грубое: глаза. Также означает лейкома, полное или частичное помутнение сетчатки.

explanatory register/style
стручки вы заморские

Offence.

Оскорбление.

register/style
заморские

Archaism: someone who lives across the sea. Ilya and Orina will have encounters with sailors later in the novel.

Архаизм: человек, который живёт за морем. Илья и Орина встречаются с моряками позже в романе.

archaism intratextuality
мусики́я

Church Slavonic: music.

Церковнославянский язык: музыка.

archaism register/style music
явился не запылился

Set expression, used when someone appears to express either irony, surprise, or displeasure.

Устойчивое выражение.

phraseologism
явился не запылился

Alliteration (ilsia).

Аллитерация (ился).

sound
вошли в его шкуру

A variation of the set expression “vlezt’ v shkuru” (get under the skin), meaning “to put oneself into one’s shoes”. Literally, the word “shkura” refers to animal skin, and it anticipates the role that fox fur will play later on in the novel. Animal motif. As Johnson notes, Ilya Zynzyrella, evoking “Cinderella of vair (or verre) slipper fame” is indeed “a male Cinderella [who] makes fur slippers for his beloved who (posthumously) seeks to be reunited with him.” He adds: “If the fur slippers are central to the intergrading of Orina and the mentally defective girls, valenki ‘felt boots’ strongly hint at the relationship between Il’ya and Yakov. It is here that we find echoes of the Oedipus legend” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 164). Shoe motif.

phraseologism motif
любезно, плеснув от души. И соблазняли: живи-ка, брат, вечно

Internal rhyme (lyubezno, vechno).

Внутренняя рифма (любезно - вечно).

rhyme
плеснув от души

Ostanin suggests that Nikolai and the itinerants begin drinking (15). Alcohol theme.

Согласно Останину, Николай и бродяги начинают пить (Ostanin 15). Тема алкоголя.

explanatory theme
живи-ка, брат, вечно

Compare to “Life-Everlastin’” (Вечная Жизнь), one of Orina’s forms and a manifestation of the Volga, which first appears in chapter 10.

Можно сравнить с “Вечной Жизнью”, одним из образов Орины и воплощением Волги, упоминаемой в главе 10.

intratextuality theme
ка

Colloquial: suffix added to imperatives to express urgency.

Разговорное: суффикс, добавляемый к императивам для выражения неотложности.

register/style
эта дама

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Угодника

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality folklore religion
что это там у вас между вами невзрачный какой на катке? Не беспокойся, это просто Николка у нас между нами катается себе на катке

Alliteration (k), rhythm structured also thanks to redundancy of the grammatical constructs (u nas mezhdu nami; kataetsja sebe).

rhythm
что это там у вас между вами невзрачный какой на катке? Не беспокойся, это просто Николка у нас между нами катается себе на катке

Rhythm + epistrophe.

Ритм + эпифора.

rhythm stylistic device
Николка

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Nikolka. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
лихо

As a noun, лихо (likho) means evil or misfortune. Accordingly, Nikolai, like several other men, will meet his demise after his time with the Dame. Here, it also means deftly, swiftly.

В форме существительного, “лихо” означает “беда, несчастье”. Соответственно, Николая, как и несколько других, настигнет смерть после встречи с Дамой.

language theme
не ахти

Colloquial: not good, bad.

Разговорное выражение.

register/style
табак его обстоятельство

A variation on the set expression “наше дело табак” (fugazi, snafu, our situation is in a bad state).

Вариация выражения “наше дело табак” — плохое положение дел.

phraseologism register/style
мысле́те выделывать

“Myslete” is the old name for the letter ‘m’. However, there is also the expression “myslete vypisyvat’” (to write out an m), that is, “to go zigzagging” (about a drunken person). Alcohol theme.

“Мыслете” - это старинное название буквы “м”. Но существует и выражение “мыслете выписывать” (о пьяном человеке), то есть “идти зигзагами”.

phraseologism archaism explanatory theme
Дама

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
нет уж, вы уж

Rhythm through repetition.

Ритм образуется повтором.

rhythm
чудить

Colloquial: to joke around, to fool around, to play hijinks. However, there is an echo of чудо (chudo, miracle) in this word, creating an association with Nikolai the Helper.

Разговорное: шутить, валять дурака. Однако, слово “чудить” также перекликается с “чудом”, строя параллель с Николаем Угодником.

register/style
неказистого

Colloquial: unsightly, plain, ugly

Разговорное: некрасивый, убогий, безобразный.

register/style
богаделы

Archaism: one who lives in an almshouse.

Архаизм: человек, который живет в приюте для престарелых и инвалидов.

archaism
Угодника

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality folklore religion
не живи-ка, брат, вечно

Compare to “Life-Everlastin’” (Вечная Жизнь), one of Orina’s forms and a manifestation of the Volga, which first appears in chapter 10. An echo-repetition of their first welcoming to Nikolai a few lines above: “zhivi-ka, brat, vechno.”

Можно сравнить с “Вечной Жизнью”, одним из образов Орины и прототипом Волги, упоминаемой в главе 10. Отголосок-повтор первого приветствия Николаю несколькими строками выше: “живи-ка, брат, вечно”.

intratextuality character
ка

Colloquial: suffix added to imperatives to express urgency.

Разговорное: суффикс, добавляемый к императивам для выражения неотложности.

register/style
немым

Nikolai is, apparently, blind, deaf, and mute. Caramitti talks about an “infinite gallery of crippled” (бесконечная галерея калек) in Sokolov’s oeuvre (“Mul’tfil’m” 363). Two of Sokolov’s early stories were about the blind as well: “The Old Helmsman” (“Staryi shturman”) and “All the Colors of the Rainbow” (“Vse tsveta radugi”). Elena Kravchenko notes a parallel between this theme in Sokolov’s first published stories and the nature of his writing in general: “They were published in Braille, the language by which corporality took the centre stage, outlasting the artefact of reality: not its expression but its embodiment” (The Prose 2).

Как выясняется, Николай слеп, глух и нем. Карамитти говорит о “бесконечной галерее калек” в творчестве Соколова (Caramitti, “Mul’tfil’m” 363). Два ранних рассказа Соколова также написаны о слепых: “Старый штурман” и “Все цвета радуги”. Е. Кравченко отмечает параллель между данным мотивом в ранних историях Соколова и его стилем письма в целом: “Они были напечатаны шрифтом Брайля — языком, благодаря которому материальность вышла на первый план, опережая артефакт реальности: не ее выражение, а ее воплощение” (Kravchenko, “The Prose” 2).

character intertextuality self-reference
пригрела

Colloquial: to welcome fondly.

Разговорное слово.

register/style
утиля

An echo of the Itil’ (Итиль) River.

Отголосок названия реки Итиль.

sound play
излишней выслугой лет у них не блеснул

He did not live long there.

Не долго ему дано было там жить.

explanatory
погорячился

Colloquial: to get upset, heat up.

Разговорное: вспылить, разозлиться.

register/style
объявится

Colloquial word: to turn up, to appear.

Разговорное: появиться.

register/style
Такова, если не возражаете, эта хроника

An echo-repetition of how this part of the story began: “Хроника его невезухи, если не возражаете, какова?” A folkloric conclusion combined with the high style of “chronicle.”

Отголосок-повтор начала истории: “Хроника его невезухи, если не возражаете, какова?” Сочетание фольклористической концовки с высоким стилем “хроники”.

register/style folklore intratextuality
если не возражаете

An example of Ilya’s conversational style/tone. Why would Pozhilykh object to Ilya’s account of Nikolai’s life?

register/style
Возникает

Ellipsis of the word “question” (vopros).

Эллипсис (“вопрос”).

register/style
неточеные

Ice skates.

Коньки

explanatory
я один из всего коллектива

A continuation of the individual/collective theme.

Продолжение темы индивида/коллектива.

theme
брезгуя

Colloquial: to be squeamish, to disdain.

Разговорное: пренебрегать

register/style
воротили нос, несмотря что и сами пачули

The other men refuse to serve Nikolai and turn up their noses. Ilya compares them to patchouli, a flowering plant known for its strong smell that is often used medicinally. Plant motif.

Остальные отказваются обслуживать Николая. Илья сравнивает их с пачули — растением, известным сильным характерным запахом и использующимся в медицине. Мотив растений.

metaphor explanatory motif
пачули

A species of plant in the Lamiaceae family (commonly names: mint and deadnettle). Known for its earthy, musky, woody smell. Characters throughout the novel are frequently associated with flora and fauna. Plant motif.

motif
не первой свежести

Set expression: not a spring chicken anymore.

Устойчивое выражение.

phraseologism
Точил

Here and further, the repetition of the verb defines the rhythm, like a refrain.

Здесь и дальше, повторение глагола образует ритм, как рефрен.

poetic device
Точил я и Гурию, и Крылобылу, и Зимарь-Человеку точил, я всему Итилю, понимаете ли, точил

The repetition of the verb defines the rhythm, like a refrain.

Здесь и дальше, повторение глагола образует ритм.

rhythm
Гурию

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
Крылобылу

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality
Зимарь

According to Boguslawski’s annotations, zimar’ refers to Andrei Voznesensky’s poem “Song-travesty from the spectacle ‘Antiworlds’” (1963) (“Annotations” 233). It combines the word zima (winter) with the ending of ianvar’ (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

Согласно аннотациям Богуславского, “зимарь” — отсылка на стихотворение Андрея Вознесенского “Песенка-травести из спектакля Антимиры” (1963) (“Аннотации” 233). Образовано сочетанием слов “зима” и “январь”, подразумевая на зимнее время. Возможно, также намек на созвездие Ориона, видимое на небе в период зимнего солнцестояния. Согласно мифологии, Орион полюбил Меропу (как и многих других женщин) и насильно овладел ею, что напоминает историю Орины. Мотив созвездий-неба.

character intertextuality time
Итилю

Metonymy (the river embodies its inhabitants). Itil’ is the Tatar name of the Volga River. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

Метонимия — река олицетворяет её обитателей. Итиль — татарское название Волги. Заглавие письма Ильи “Заитильщина” является производным от этой версии названия реки. Остатин также указывает на фонетическое сходство рек Итиль и Леты, реки забытья, которая также играет важную роль в первом романе Соколова “Школа для дураков” (Ostanin 10).

setting poetic device location foreign language
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
Хлебом

Ilya will repeatedly use phrases related to flour (vs. torment) and bread throughout his letter.

Илья неоднократно использует в письме фразы, относящиеся к муке (также, в смысле “страдания”) и хлебу

symbol metaphor
Хлебом, бывало, его не корми

Set expression meaning to have a strong passion for something.

Устойчивое выражение, означающее непреодолимую страсть к чему-либо.

phraseologism
Хлебом, бывало, его не корми — дай разлететься по скользкому

Dak5.

Дак5.

metrical pattern
перепадет, словно бы долгожданный в засуху дождь

Perepast’ can mean to drop by or to fall into, but, colloquially, it can also refer to rain falling. Here, Gury “flies into” the co-op but is also equated to rain.

“Перепасть” означает “достаться”, “упасть”, но в разговорном языке может также относиться к дождю. Здесь, Гурий “влетает” в мастерскую, но приравнивается к дождю.

register/style explanatory poetic device
подустал

Colloquial: to tire a little bit.

Разговорное: слегка устать.

register/style
Вышел Гурий из тумана, вынул ножик из кармана, стану я тот нож точить, а тебе — вина тащить

Ch4*4.

Х4*4.

metrical pattern
Вышел Гурий из тумана, вынул ножик из кармана, стану я тот нож точить, а тебе — вина тащить.

Variation a popular counting-out rhyme.

Детская считалка, здесь обработана и переделана. Cуществуют разные варианты, например: “Вышел немец из тумана, / Вынул ножик из кармана, / Буду резать, буду бить - / С кем останешься дружить?”, или” Вышел месяц из тумана, / Вынул ножик из кармана. / Буду резать, буду бить – / Всё равно тебе водить!”

intertextuality
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
вина

The characters are all prone to excessive drinking. Alcohol theme.

Все герои склонны к чрезмерному пьянству. Тема алкоголя.

theme
чеботу

A shoe with a slight heel, boot, and curved toe. Yakov mentions in Note 2 that the “lonesome babe” chides him for abandoning his boots (R165/E29). D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Сапоги с каблуком, высоким голенищем и загнутым носком. Яков рассказывает в Записке II о “бобылке”, укоряющей его за то, что он не надел свои сапоги (R165/E29). Д. Бартон Джонсон считает мотив обуви принципиально значимым в трех романах Соколова: “дань, будь то осознанная или неосознанная, традициям русской литературы, представленным его предшественниками — И. Буниным и В. Катаевым (Johnson, “The Galoshes Manifesto” 179). В интервью с А. и H. Воронель Соколов называет Бунина и Гоголя “современниками, сотрудниками по цеху, старшими мастерами” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Мотив обуви.

intratextuality motif intertextuality
снегурок

A type of ice skates, usually for beginners. In this picture: Ivan Tolstoy’s (son of Lev Tolstoy) snegurki.

explanatory
рашпилю

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

Заимствовано от немецкого Raspel. Напильник. Изображено ниже:

foreign
рашпиль
