Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

Заимствовано из немецкого языка. Напильник. Изображено ниже:

foreign
запропастился

Colloquial: to disappear, to go missing.

Разговорное: пропасть, исчезнуть.

register/style
либо коллеги его заиграли

Dak4.

Дак4.

metrical pattern
заиграли

Slang: to appropriate. The first of several potential thefts that play a central role in the novel.

Жаргон: украсть, прибрать к рукам. Первая из серии потенциальных краж, которая играет ключевую роль в романе.

theme register/style
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

intratextuality character
что ты ищешь, скажи. Я сказал. Он сказал им

An4.

Ан4.

metrical pattern
скажи. Я сказал. Он сказал

The repetition of the same verb stresses the rhythmic reading of the passage.

Повтор глагола подчеркивает ритмическое чтение.

rhythm
стру́мент

Colloquial/low: instrument.

Разговорное, сокращенно от “инструмент”.

register/style
заиграл

Slang: to appropriate.

Жаргон: украсть

register/style
корешок

Colloquial: a diminutive form of ко́реш (kóresh) — male friend, buddy, pal, mate, crony.

Разговорное: уменьшительная форма от “кореш” — братан, чувак, друган.

register/style
обыскался

Colloquial: to search for something for a long time.

Разговорное: долго что-то искать.

register/style
артель

Metonymy.

Метонимия.

poetic device
отзынь

Slang: beat it! bug off!

register/style
долбаный

Colloquial/low: unpleasant, disgusting, abnormal.

Разговорное, вульгарное: неприятный, нежелательный.

register/style
рашпиль

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

Заимствовано от немецкого Raspel. Напильник. Изображено ниже:

foreign
рашпиле

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

Заимствовано от немецкого Raspel. Напильник. Изображено ниже:

foreign
Сло́боду

The stress should fall on the last syllable. In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Ударение должно падать на последний слог.

В Древней Руси, поселение в Поволжье, Центральной России, Беларуси или Украине. Образовано от слова “свобода”. Подобные поселения, свободные от повинностей, были упразднены в начале XVIII века и стали обыкновенными деревнями. Зачастую, пригородные районы поглощались близлежащими городами. В современном языке, “слобода” в разных областях относится к населенному пункту в сельской местности.

location Russia
кубарэ

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

Необычное (и мнимо-иностранное) слово, наверное от разговорного морского термина “кубарь”, каюта.

foreign neologism location setting
Слободу

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

В Древней Руси, поселение в Поволжье, Центральной России, Беларуси или Украине. Образовано от слова “свобода”. Подобные поселения, свободные от повинностей, были упразднены в начале XVIII века и стали обыкновенными деревнями. Зачастую, пригородные районы поглощались близлежащими городами. В современном языке, “слобода” в разных областях относится к населенному пункту в сельской местности.

location Russia
семь верст киселя хлебать

Set expression: to travel a long distance for a silly or no real purpose.

Устойчивое выражение: проделать долгий путь ради незначительной цели или вовсе без неё.

phraseologism
верст

An obsolete Russian unit of length equal to approximately .66 miles or 1.07 km.

Устаревшая русская мера длины, соответствующая примерно 0,66 милям или 1,7 км.

Russia explanatory
киселя

A fruit dish served in the form of a dessert or a drink made of berry juice and a starch agent

Фруктовое блюдо, подающееся в виде десерта или напитка, приготовленного из ягодного сока и крахмала.

explanatory
на рашпиле там или на дурашпиле

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
рашпиле

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

Заимствовано от немецкого Raspel. Напильник. Изображено ниже:

foreign
дурашпиле

A neologistic play on rashpil (Raspel) combining the German word with durak (fool). Emphasizes the foolish nature of this quest.

Неологистическая игра слов “рашпиль” (нем.) и “дурак”. Подчеркивает бессмысленность мероприятия.

neologism foreign pun irony
ибо

Literary/dated: because, for.

Устаревшее/книжное слово: потому что.

register/style
жертва жребия

A possible reference to Lermontov’s poem “Epiphany.” Read the original here and an English translation here.

Возможная отсылка к “Эпитафии” Лермонтова: “И смерть захочет ли свести / Две жертвы жребия земного, /Как знать! Итак, прости, прости!..”

intertextuality
жертва жребия

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
таранит в торбе на мощном горбу стеклотару

Ilya is carrying with him a number of empty glass bottles, presumably to sell. Alcohol theme.

Илья несёт пустые стеклянные бутылки, предположительно, для продажи.

explanatory theme
торбе

Colloquial: bag, sack.

Разговорное: сумка, мешок.

register/style
горбу

Ilya is hunchbacked. The image of humpbacked people and animals appears several times throughout the novel (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208).

Илья страдает кифозом (горбатостью). Образ горбатых людей и животных неоднократно встречается в романе: (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208).

explanatory intratextuality character
долинах и взгорьях

Borrowed from a Soviet Civil War song: “Through Valleys and Over Hills” (“По долинам и по взгорьям”): “Through valleys and over hills / The division went on.” A recording is available here.

intertextuality music
взгорьях

Colloquial: a slight hill. Mirrors Ilya’s hunch.

Разговорное: небольшой холм. Намёк на горбатость Ильи.

register/style
не в курсе

Ilya’s letter, of course, is written to Pozhilykh, but such statements often seem to address the reader directly.

Письмо Ильи, очевидно, адресовано Пожилых, но засчёт подобных фраз зачастую кажется, что он обращается напрямую к читателю.

explanatory
предуведомить

Archaism/officialese: to notify in advance.

Официальное/архаизм: заранее предупредить

register/style
кубарэ

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

Необычное (и мнимо-иностранное) слово, наверное от разговорного морского термина “кубарь”, каюта.

foreign neologism location setting
гордыни

Bookish/dated: pride, arrogance.

Книжный, уст.: гордость, высокомерие.

register/style
дают коммерческий мах

Colloquial: to make a mistake.

Разговорное выражение: ошибиться.

register/style
забегаловке

Colloquial: an eatery of not high quality.

Разговорное: столовая или закусочная не очень высокого качества.

register/style
цене, без капризов, а оплаченное имеешь право употребить как в помещении, так и вне.

Internal rhyme (cene - i vne).

Внутренная рифма (цене - и вне).

sound
И Гурий

A continuation of Gury’s conversation with the other grinders from above, interrupted by Ilya’s commentary on commerce in the region.

Продолжение разговора Гурия с точильщиками, прерванного замечаниями Ильи насчёт торговых отношений в регионе.

explanatory structure
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
напрямик

Colloquial: directly, openly, point-blank.

Разговорное: напрямую, открыто.

register/style
рашпиле

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

Заимствовано от немецкого Raspel. Напильник. Изображено ниже:

foreign
Илье

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
рашпиле

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

Заимствовано от немецкого Raspel. Напильник. Изображено ниже:

foreign
не с руки

Colloquial phrase: inconvenient, lacking sense.

Разговорное выражение: неудобно, неловко.

register/style phraseologism
подначивать

Colloquial: to egg on, tease, provoke.

Разговорное: дразнить, подзадоривать, провоцировать.

register/style
Пожилых

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character intertextuality religion
марафонить

Slang: to binge. Alcohol theme.

Жаргон: долго бежать на коньках.

register/style
марафонить известный мастак, вон мослы-то себе отрастил — первый сорт

Аn4x2.

Ан4x2.

metrical pattern
мастак

Low: a master, a whiz, a person skilled in something.

Просторечное: мастер, умелец, опытный в своём деле человек.

register/style
мослы

Low: bones, particularly femurs.

Просторечное: выступащие из-под кожи кости, конкретно, бедренные.

register/style
с нашими бестолковыми моськами, в калашный ряд

A variation on the phrase: со свиным рылом в калашный ряд (to put your snout where it doesn’t belong).

Разновидность фразы “со свиным рылом в калашный ряд” — совать свой нос, куда не следует.

phraseologism
моськами

Low: a mug (as in an ugly face) or a small dog. The grinders associate themselves with dogs (as opposed to wolves) here. Animal-human motif.

Просторечное: рожа или небольшая собака. Точильщики здесь сравнивают себя с собаками (в противопоставление волкам). Мотив животных-людей.

register/style motif
в калашный ряд

Colloquial phrase: in an inappropriate place.

Разговорная фраза: в неподходящем месте.

phraseologism register/style
паче

Archaism: even more so, more.

Архаизм: тем более.

register/style archaism
Илье

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
Безобразнику

Colloquial: scamp, hooligan, someone who behaves foolishly, monstrous. Literally: without image.

Разговорное: озорник, хулиган, человек, который глупо себя ведёт. Буквально: без образа.

register/style character
Так, докладывал егерь Манул, ходивший по щепетильным нуждам в Иные Места, что встречал там страшилищей и почище.

This scene is revisited in chapter 4 (R176/E47).

Это сцена описана подробнее в главе 4 (R176/E47).

intratextuality
Манул

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

Манул, также палласов кот — дикий кот, впервые замеченный в районе Прибайкалья. Останин также предполагает, что имя героя —сокращенная форма имени Иммануил, которое означает “С нами Бог” (Ostanin 16). Изображён ниже:

Илья упоминает “манульи глаза” в главе 6 (R192/E76). Мотив животных.

character intratextuality motif
щепетильным

Archaism: scrupulous, fastidious.

Архаизм: скурпулёзный, дотошный.

archaism register/style
Иные Места

Generally abroad, in other countries. The use of the capital letters also suggests a more metaphysical location, the other side of the river, the opposition between life and death.

За границей, другие страны.

foreign location explanatory theme
страшилищей и почище

Alliteration (sh/sch).

Аллитерация (ш/щ).

sound stylistic device
покуда

Low: while, at the same time.

Просторечное: пока, в то время как.

register/style
кой-как

Colloquial form of кое-как (with difficulty, poorly).

Разговорная форма от “кое-как” (с трудом, плохо)

register/style
клепало

A hammer for riveting. Also an archaic term for “bell.” Also mentioned in chapter 16 (R275/E220).

Молот для клепания. Устаревшее название колокола. Также упоминается в главе 16 (R275/E220).

intratextuality explanatory archaism
бесталанным

Archaic/poetic: unfortunate, unlucky.

Архаизм/поэтическое: несчастливый, неудачливый.

archaism register/style
Илье

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
рашпиль

Borrowed from the German Raspel. A coarse file.

Заимствовано от немецкого Raspel. Напильник. Изображено ниже:

foreign
под градусом

Colloquial phrase: to be tipsy. Alcohol theme.

Разговорное: слегка пьяный, навеселе. Тема алгоколя.

phraseologism register/style theme
поелику

Archaism: because.

Архаизм: поэтому.

archaism register/style
затишке

Same as затишок. Colloquial word: a place that is calm, free from strong winds.

Разговорное: спокойное место, укрытое от сильных ветров.

register/style
наддав

Colloquial: to accelerate.

Разговорное: ускорить.

register/style
Слободу

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

В Древней Руси, поселение в Поволжье, Центральной России, Беларуси или Украине. Образовано от слова “свобода”. Подобные поселения, свободные от повинностей, были упразднены в начале XVIII века и стали обыкновенными деревнями. Зачастую, пригородные районы поглощались близлежащими городами. В современном языке, “слобода” в разных областях относится к населенному пункту в сельской местности.

location Russia
Тары-бары

Colloquial word: chitchat, tittle-tattle, meaningless chatter.

Разговорное: болтовня, бессмысленная беседа.

register/style
Тары-бары

Alliteration.

sound stylistic device
рассусоливаю

Low: to say, to talk.

Просторечное: разговаривать, беседовать.

register/style
недосуг

Colloquial: lack of time.

Разговорное: нехватка времени.

register/style
куплю

Archaism: purchase.

archaism register/style
дую

Colloquial usage: to go quickly.

Разговорное употребление: быстро идти.

register/style
вспять

Archaism: back(ward).

Архаизм: назад

archaism register/style
сумерки так и вьются над глупой моей башкой

Twilight will be Ilya’s downfall when he mistakes Yakov’s dog for a wolf. Here, it whirls above and, in a sense, becomes entwined with his head. Again, Ilya stresses his simplicity and modesty, defining his head as “stupid.”

Сумерки станут погибелью Ильи, когда он примет за волка собаку Якова. Здесь, сумерки вьются над его головой и, в каком-то смысле, становятся с ней одним целым. Илья снова подчёркивает свою простоту и скромность, называя свою голову “глупой”.

character theme
над глупой моей башкой

Kh4М; internal rhyme.

Х4М; внутренная рифма.

sound metrical pattern
башкой

Colloquial: head. Archaism: head of a large fish, head meat. Used several times throughout the novel (R152, 174, 189, 264, 280).

Разговорное: голова. Архаизм: голова крупой рыбы, головизна (мясо головы). Несколько раз встречается в романе (R152, 174, 189, 264, 280).

register/style archaism intratextuality
Даниилы

A reference to D. Zatochnika (Д. Заточника) near the beginning of this chapter. Metonymy: his companions at the artel.

Отсылка к артели имени Д. Заточника, упоминаемой в начале главы. Метонимия: его товарищи в артели.

intratextuality intertextuality
паче

Archaism: even more so, more..

Архаизм: тем более.

archaism register/style
паче чаяния

Archaic set expression: unexpectedly, against all expectations.

Устаревшее устойчивое выражение: вопреки ожидания.

phraseologism archaism
цехов

Archaism: guild (as in the workshops).

Архаизм: организация ремесленников одной профессии.

archaism register/style
горемык

Archaism/poetic: someone continually plagued by misfortunes.

Архаизм, поэтическое: человек, постоянно преследуемый несчастьями

register/style archaism
подначивала

Colloquial: to egg on, tease, provoke.

Разговорное: дразнить, подзадоривать, провоцировать.

register/style
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

intratextuality character
пасы́

Idiomatic: to cry uncle, to admit defeat. This expression is usually use in the singular.

Идиоматическое: сдаваться, признавать поражение.

phraseologism
Так, механики, так,

Repetition.

Повтор.

sound
сухой

In the sense of lean, wiry, capable.

В смысле подтянутый, выносливый, в форме

language
Поглядите, он им сказал, поглядите

Repetition.

Повтор.

sound
индев

An echo of the individual/invalid sound used earlier.

Отголосок слов “индивид”, “инвалид”

sound play
эдакого

Archaism/colloquial: the same as этакий (such, like, any kind of).

Архаизм/разговорное: этакий, такой

archaism register/style
обшаркал

Low: to snuff out, to defeat.

Просторечное: победить, обойти

register/style
сей

Archaism: this.

Архаизм: этот

archaism register/style
Воскурили

Colloquial: to begin smoking.

Разговорное: начать курить

register/style
Воскурили, заспорили и вышли на холод перекурить

An6.

An6.

metrical pattern
за нами град деревянен, велик, там мужик брандахлыстничает вовсю, а внизу, перед нами, плес — как на ладошке застыл

Dak7 with an exceptional stress + An5.

Dak7 со сверхмерным ударением + Aн5.

metrical pattern
град

Archaism: city (город).

Архаизм: город

archaism register/style
брандахлыст

Archaism/colloquial: a drink that is too runny, watery. Archaism/colloquial: an idler, a worthless person. Alcohol theme.

Архаизм/разговорное: слишком жидкий напиток. Архаизм/разговорное: бездельник, бесполезный человек. Тема алкоголя.

neologism archaism register/style theme
вовсю

Colloquial: as much as possible, to the utmost.

Разговорное: как можно больше, до предела

register/style
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

intratextuality character
Малокулебяково

A town on the banks of the river.

Город на берегу реки

location setting
кулебяко

Сoulibiac (кулебяка, kulebiaka): a Russian pie pastry (pirog) typically filled with salmon or sturgeon, rice or buckwheat, hard-boiled eggs, mushrooms, onions, and dill.

Кулебяка — русский пирог обычно с мясом, лососем или осетром, рисом, гречкой, сваренными яйцами, грибами, луком, укропом. Изображен здесь:

explanatory Russia
Ну и кто же у нас там живет?

An3.

Ан3.

metrical pattern
Мало ли в Кулебякове

The workmen split up the name of the town when answering Gury’s question and from here, it loses part of its name. An example of incorrect segmentation characteristic for illiterate people.

Отвечая на вопрос Гурия, артельщики разбивают название селения, и часть названия теряется

location language
Кулебяк

Сoulibiac (кулебяка, kulebiaka): a Russian pie pastry (pirog) typically filled with salmon or sturgeon, rice or buckwheat, hard-boiled eggs, mushrooms, onions, and dill.

Кулебяка — русский пирог обычно с мясом, лососем или осетром, рисом, гречкой, сваренными яйцами, грибами, луком, укропом. Изображен здесь:

Russia
мельник

Miller, related to the term мельница (mill, melnitsa), playing on the connection between “milling” and “pastries.” Sokolov will use the connection between torment (мука)/flour (мука) several times throughout the novel as well.

Слово “мельник” (работник мельницы) указывает на связь между “молотьбой” и “выпечкой”. Соколов несколько раз возвращается к связи между мукой (страданием) и мукой (хлебопекарной) на протяжении всего романа.

metaphor intratextuality
земля едва носит, не то что лед

Set expression: bad/negative person. This phraseologism (barely carried by the earth) is further expanded and concretized: “ne to chto led” (not to mention the ice).

Устойчивое выражение: плохой/отрицательный человек. Здесь фразеологизм расширен и дополнен: “не то что лёд”.

phraseologism language style
на мельнице у мельника чурка числится

Rhythmic passage played on an etymological figure and alliteration (ch).

Ритмическый обрывок с этимологической фигурой и аллитерацией.

rhythm stylistic device sound
мельника

Miller, related to the term мельница (mill, melnitsa), playing on the connection between “milling” and “pastries.” Sokolov will use the connection between torment (мука)/flour (мука) several times throughout the novel as well.

Слово “мельник” (работник мельницы) указывает на связь между “молотьбой” и “выпечкой”. Соколов несколько раз возвращается к связи между мукой (страданием) и мукой (хлебопекарной) на протяжении всего романа.

metaphor character
чурка

Derogatory slur referring to a person from the Caucasus or Central Asia.

Оскорбление, относящееся к уроженцу Кавказа или Центральной Азии.

register/style
Аладдин

Mentioned four times in the novel with different surnames (R153/E7, R199/E89, R242/E161, R278/E225). The name of Arabic origin Aladdin (Al al-Din) means “nobility of faith” and was popularized by the success of One Thousand and One Nights, before the 1992 homonymous Disney movie. Here it is used to suggest the Tatar origin of the character (directly indicated in Note XIV). His last name is mentioned alternatively as Batrutdinov and Rakhmatullin: the first derives from the Arabic name Batrutdin which means “full moon of the faith”; the second is a Tatar or Bashkir last name, derived from the name Rahmatullah, “mercy of God.”

Четыре раза встречается в романе под разными фамилиями (R153/E7, R199/E89, R242/E161, R278/E225).

character intratextuality intertextuality religion
Кулебяк

Сoulibiac (кулебяка, kulebiaka): a Russian pie pastry (pirog) typically filled with salmon or sturgeon, rice or buckwheat, hard-boiled eggs, mushrooms, onions, and dill.

Кулебяка — русский пирог обычно с мясом, лососем или осетром, рисом, гречкой, сваренными яйцами, грибами, луком, укропом. Изображен здесь:

Russia
Кулебякове

The town has lost the beginning of its name: Мало (Malo).

Утеряно начало названия селения “Мало”

location setting language
по слухам

Much of the novel, of course, involves rumors and gossip, mixing up stories and potential realities.

Большая часть романа построена на слухах и сплетнях, в результате чего путаются истории и потенциальные реальности

explanatory structure
в сухой колодец упал

Sokolov explains: “This is an ordinary village well with a windlass. The bucket is lowered and lifted with the aid of a windlass and a rope wrapped around it. From time to time in some village someone falls into the well wanting to draw water. Sometimes a child, sometimes a drunken adult. Sometimes a dog or a cat. If there is water in the well, the victim drowns. But if the well is dry, there is a chance that sooner or later the person or animal will be pulled out. They will if people hear screams or meows for help. It is impossible to get out of the well by yourself. The huntsman Ilya tells us about most likely fell into the well, as they say, because he was drunk, and his wife hastened to take advantage of this circumstance. There is nothing allegorical in the fall of the huntsman into the well” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “Имеется в виду обычный деревенский колодец с воротом. С помощью ворота и намотанной на него веревки осуществляют спуск и подъем ведра. Время от времени то в той деревне, то в этой кто-нибудь, желая зачерпнуть воды, падает в колодец. Иногда ребенок, иногда пьяный взрослый. Подчас собака или кошка. Если в колодце есть вода, жертва тонет. А если колодец сухой, то есть шанс, что рано или поздно человека или животное вытащат оттуда. Вытащат, если услышат крики или мяуканья о помощи. Самому выбраться из колодца невозможно. Егерь, о котором рассказывает Илья, скорее всего угодил в колодец, как говорится, по пьяному делу, и жена его этим обстоятельством поспешила воспользоваться. В падении егеря в колодец нет ничего иносказательного” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory Russia
сухой

Gury was just described as a сухой (lean, wiry) runner.

Гурий только что был охарактеризован как “сухой” бегун

sound play character
супруга

Bureaucratese.

Официальный стиль.

register/style
безынтересно

Without interest but also without pursuing one’s interests (archaism).

Без интереса, желания (архаизм)

archaism register/style
с соседом фигли-мигли у ней — тоже егерем, но молодей

Internal rhyme.

Внутренняя рифма.

rhyme
фигли-мигли

Colloquial: hanky-panky, affair, romance. Recalls the sound “скирлы” in A School for Fools.

Разговорное: шуры-муры, шашни, роман на стороне.

register/style theme self-reference
молодей

Incorrect form for “younger” (should be “molozhe”).

Неправильная форма прилагательного (вместо “моложе”).

language register/style
задурил

Colloquial: to seduce, deceive. Also: to act like a fool, to confuse, to lose reason.

Разговорное: соблазнить, обмануть, охмурить. Также: глупо себя вести, потерять рассудок.

register/style
таки

A colloquial emphatic particle.

Разговорная эмфатическая частица.

register/style
Плосках

A village in the Tver’ oblast. Ostanin provides several extensive lists explaining the novel’s geography and topography, which, like so much else in the novel, doesn’t always match up (17).

Деревня в Тверской области. Останин подробно разъясняет топографию и географию романа, которые, как и зачастую в других частях романа, не сходится с их описаниями в тексте.

location Russia
обретается

Archaism: to be found, to live.

Архаизм: найтись, появиться, ожить.

archaism register/style
Николай

A Nikolai different from Nikolai the Helper, introduced above. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

Другой Николай, не относящийся к Николаю Угоднику, описанному выше.

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
у которого имени собственного не было

Characters’ identities are constantly in flux.

Личности героев романа непрерывно меняются.

explanatory character structure
никогда, верней, было, но слишком давно

See also A School for Fools: “The station had a name… / The river had a name.”

См. тоже “Станция называлась / Река называлась” в “Школе для дураков.”

self-reference
Николаю Угоднику

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
преображение

Death. The reference is to the biblical Transfiguration of Jesus, in which Jesus goes to a mountaintop to pray with James, John, and Mark. Once there, he begins to shine with light, and Elijah (one of Ilya’s identities in the novel) and Moses appear beside him as the voice of God calls out to him. The event is documented in Matthew 17:1–8, Mark 9:2–8, and Luke 9:28–36. Celebrated on August 6. The main character of Mikhail Bulgakov’s Heart of a Dog (a novel which widely circulated in samizdat in the 60s) is Doctor Preobrazhensky, whose experiment of turning a homeless dog into a man leads to tragic consequences (and to his “transfigurating” back into a dog). Locally, this concept and its relationship to death also figures prominently in Note XVIII (R204–205/E95–96).

Смерть. Отсылка к библейскому Преображению Иисуса, когда Иисус поднимается на гору с Иаковом, Иоанном и Марком. Там, на вершине, он начинает сиять, а рядом с ним появляются пророк Илия (одна из личностей Ильи в романе) и Моисей, в то время как к нему взывает Божий голос. Это событие описано в Матфея 17:1-8, Марка 9:2-8, Луки 9:28-36. Празднуется 6 августа. Кроме того, главный герой романа Михаила Булгакова “Сердце собаки” (одно из массовых произведений самиздата 60-ых) — доктор Преображенский, чей эксперимент по превращению бездомного пса в человека ведет к плачевному исходу (и его “преображению” обратно в собаку). Локально, концепция преображения и ее связь со смертью играет значительную роль в Записке XVIII (R204–205/E95–96).

explanatory language intertextuality intratextuality bible religion theme
урвал

Colloquial: to snatch, to grab up.

Разговорное: присвоить, забрать.

register/style
добру пропасть

Set expression: to go to waste.

Устойчивое выражение: пропасть зря.

phraseologism
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
потаскивает

Colloquial: to steal away a bit or occasionally.

Разговорное: периодически или немного красть.

register/style
рыбари

Fishermen.

Рыбаки.

language
выискали

Colloquial: to find, to discover.

Разговорное: найти, обнаружить.

register/style
снедать

Archaism: to destroy, to wipe out, to eat.

Архаизм: уничтожать, гнобить, съедать.

archaism register/style
Так, Гурий, так, твари на воле, в тенетах

Alliteration (t).

Аллитерация (т).

sound
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
ничьи

Colloquial: nobody’s.

Разговорное: никому не принадлежащие.

register/style
Чьи

God’s.

Бога.

religion
Николу

Nikolai’s name shortens to Nikola. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Nikolka/Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

Сокращенная форма имени “Николай”.

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
порешили

Colloquial/low: to kill, to bump off, to take out.

Разговорное/просторечное: убить, прикончить.

register/style
некогда

Literary: once, at some point.

Литературное: однажды.

register/style
вентерей

A fyke or hoop net: Used to catch fish, a fyke net is made of cylindrical netting that is set into place beneath the water’s surface. It allows fish to enter but makes their exit difficult. Animal motif.

Рыболовная снасть-ловушка: Применяется в рыбной ловле. Представляет собой цилиндрическую сетку, которая устанавливается у поверхности воды. Рыба может без труда вплыть в ловушку, но не может выплыть. Мотив животных.

explanatory motif
салазки

A small sled.

Небольшие сани/санки.

explanatory
Знобко

Colloquial: to shiver, to freeze.

Разговорное: холодно, зябко.

register/style
Знобко ему, очи ему

Repetition (emu-emu).

Повтор (ему-ему).

sound
очи

Archaism for “eyes.”

Архаизм: глаза.

archaism register/style
очи

Assonans (ochi-pristavucij).

Ассонанс (очи-приставучий).

sound
дальновидные

As Ilya already wrote, Nikolai is blind (and deaf and mute), so this sounds ironic.

Как Илья описал ранее, Николай слепой (а также глухой и немой), поэтому это звучит определенно иронично.

explanatory irony character
валенки

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. The one-legged Ilya will be associated with the trapper who lives under the stairs and works with animal furs. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Традиционные русские валяные сапоги. Изображены ниже:

Мотив обуви.

motif Russia intertextuality intratextuality
прохудились

Colloquial: to become thin, leaky. The same word is used to describe a train car (R159/E18) and a samovar (R187/E67).

Разговорное: испортиться, истончиться, протечь. Такое же слово используется для описания вагона (R159/E18) и самовара (R187/E67).

register/style intratextuality
Волколис

A folkloric creature. Wolves and foxes, despite what Sokolov suggests in his response to Ostanin’s annotations, cannot crossbreed (Sokolov, “Bol’shoe” 124). Animal motif.

Мифическое существо. Волки и лисы, вопреки ответу Соколова на аннотации Останина, не могут скрещиваться (Sokolov, “Bol’shoe” 124).

explanatory folklore
приставучий

Colloquial: annoying, pestering.

Разговорное: назойливый, надоедливый.

register/style
Кинь

Here: to toss, to give. But кинуть in criminal slang may also mean to steal or to swindle, which is in keeping with the novel’s plot and Nikola/i’s aforementioned activities.

Здесь: бросить, дать. Но в криминальном жаргоне “кинуть” может иметь значение “украсть”, что сочетается с сюжетом романа и вышеупомянутыми занятиями Николая.

register/style explanatory
Кинь рыбешку, Николаю грозит, кинь вторую, а то темноту на Итиль напущу

These are Volkolis’s words, threatening Nikolai.

Слова Волколиса, угрожающие Николаю

explanatory
Николаю

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
кинь

Here: to toss, to give. But кинуть in criminal slang may also mean to steal or to swindle, which is in keeping with the novel’s plot and Nikola/i’s aforementioned activities.

register/style
Итиль

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location foreign language setting
Николая

Nikola –> Nikolay. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
Плосковского

A village in the Tver’ oblast. Ostanin provides several extensive lists explaining the novel’s geography and topography, which, like so much else in the novel, doesn’t always match up (17).

Деревня в Тверской области. Останин подробно разъясняет топографию и географию романа, которые, как и зачастую в других частях романа, не сходится с их описаниями в тексте.

location Russia
пуще

Colloquial: more than, worse than.

Разговорное: больше, хуже.

register/style
осетров

Freshwater sturgeon. Animal motif.

Пресноводный осетр:

Мотив животных.

motif
Волколису

A folkloric creature. Wolves and foxes, despite what Sokolov suggests in his response to Ostanin’s annotations, cannot crossbreed (Sokolov, “Bol’shoe” 124). Animal motif.

Мифическое существо. Волки и лисы, вопреки ответу Соколова на аннотации Останина, не могут скрещиваться (Sokolov, “Bol’shoe” 124). Мотив животных.

explanatory motif folklore
Ибо

Literary/dated: because, for.

Книжное/устаревшее: потому что.

register/style
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

Главное место действия романа: вымышленный город на берегу Волги, также называется Городнищи. Название получено в результате сочетания слов “город” и “нищий”. Таким образом, Городнищи — город нищих. О. Матич пишет: “Если Школа для дураков была написана в противовес молодежной прозе, следующий роман Соколова, Между собакой и волком можно расценивать как ответ автора на деревенскую прозу, модное литературное направление семидесятых” (Matich “Sasha Sokolov” 310). В. Крейд замечает, что Городнище, барачный город нищих и воров, напоминает “Анти-Китеж” (Китеж — мифический город в русском фольклоре, в который попадают только чистые сердцем). В Городнище, однако, воры грабят нищих, и нищие попрошайничают у грабителей (Kreid “Zaitil’shchina” 213). Согласно Джонсону, Городнище — обитель живых, в то время как мертвые населяют противоположный берег реки, в Быдогощах (Johnson “Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Джонсон также цитирует самого Соколова: “Соколов замечает, что название города является помесью развратного города XVIII века Городни, описанного А. Н. Радищевым в Путешествии из Петербурга в Москву и близлежащего города Городище. Таким образом, временные слои XVI века, XVIII века и мифического настоящего накладываются друг на друга — типичный роману прием” (217).

location intertextuality setting folklore theme symbol
дотемна не поспеть

The characters, particularly Ilya, struggle in this hour between light and the dark. Nighttime brings on their conflicts and confusions.

Герои, в частности Илья, тяжело переносят час между дневным светом и ночной темнотой. Ночь раскрывает их конфликты и недоразумения.

intratextuality theme time
средств за товар не выручить, средств за товар не выручить — в кубарэ не зайти, в кубарэ не зайти — со товарищи не гулять, а со товарищи не гулять

These repetitions are seemingly murmured by Nikolai trying to reach the village before dark.

Вероятно, слова пробормотаны Ильей, который старается успеть в деревню до темноты.

explanatory
средств за товар не выручить, средств за товар не выручить — в кубарэ не зайти, в кубарэ не зайти — со товарищи не гулять, а со товарищи не гулять

Rhythmic repetition.

Ритмический повтор.

rhythm
кубарэ

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

Необычное (и мнимо-иностранное) слово, наверное от разговорного морского термина “кубарь”, каюта.

foreign neologism location
кубарэ

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

Необычное (и мнимо-иностранное) слово, наверное от разговорного морского термина “кубарь”, каюта.

foreign neologism location
со товарищи

Colloquial: a grammatical error.

register/style
гулять

Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb gulyat’ is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina will be defined as gulyaschaya: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). In her case, “гулена” means “party person,” and “гулящая” is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

Разговорное: развлекаться, отдыхать. Частое употребление глагола “гулять” связано с определением Орины в главе 10 как “гулящей”: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124).

register/style intratextuality
гулять

Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb gulyat’ is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina will be defined as gulyaschaya: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). In her case, “гулена” means “party person” and “гулящая” is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

Разговорное: развлекаться, отдыхать. Частое употребление глагола “гулять” связано с определением Орины в главе 10 как “гулящей”: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). В данном случае, “гулена” относится к пристрастию Орины к застольям и пиршествам, а “гулящая” указывает на ее беспорядочные романтические отношения.

register/style intratextuality
лямку тянуть

Set expression: to drudge, pull weight, toil. Literally “to pull the strap.” A set expression meaning to labor with great difficulty. It is usually associated with Repin’s painting “Burlaki”.

Устойчивое выражение, означающее “тяжелый труд”. Ассоциируется с картиной Репина “Бурлаки на Волге”. Изображено ниже:

register/style phraseologism intertextuality
Пожилых

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character intertextuality religion
дреколье

Archaic: clubs.

Aрхаизм: Дубина.

archaism
Николая

Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
осетров

Freshwater sturgeon. Animal motif.

motif
зеленых склизких линей

Alliteration (l).

Аллитерация (л).

sound stylistic device
склизких

Low: smooth, slick.

Просторечное: скользкий, гладкий.

register/style
линей

Tench. Also known as the doctor fish. A fresh- and brackish-water fish. Animal motif.

Линь, также известный как “рыба-доктор”. Водится в пресных и полупресных водоемах. Изображено ниже:

Мотив животных.

motif
Мол

Colloquial: he says.

Разговорное: он говорит.

register/style
лубяной веселеющий град

That is, Gorodnishche, a wooden town, as suggested above.

То есть, Городнище, деревянный город (как указано выше).

location setting
град

Archaism: city (город).

Архаизм: город.

archaism register/style
исполать

Archaism: glory, praise.

Архаизм: хвала, слава.

archaism register/style
тараканьи терема

Sokolov explains: “Cockroaches often infest houses in Northern villages. Village cockroaches differ from city cockroaches: village cockroaches are bigger, but they are nicer: they are black, not yellow, and not so arrogant. In poor farms there are not many cockroaches or none: there is nothing for them to do in the canteen - food is scarce. But in the terem, as Ilya probably thinks, people live richer, they have more food and, therefore, lots of cockroaches” (personal communication, June 7, 2023). Animal motif.

Соколов объясняет: “В домах северных деревень нередко заводятся тараканы. Деревенские тараканы отличаются от городских: деревенские крупнее, но симпатичнее: хотя бы потому, что они черные, а не желтые, и не такие наглые. В бедных хозяйствах тараканов мало или они отсутствуют: там ведь по буфету особенно не разгуляешься - скудная там снедь. А в теремах, как, вероятно, думает Илья, живут люди побогаче, еды у них, значит, больше и, следовательно, имеется много тараканов” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory Russia motif
град

Archaism: city (город).

Архаизм: город.

archaism register/style
град, на грядущую

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

stylistic device sound
грядущую ночь

Nikolay approaches the town and faces his impending death during twilight.

Николай приближается к городу и встречает неминуемую смерть в час сумерек.

time theme
убиенного недругами невезучего рыбаря

Nikolay seems to predict his own death at the hands of his colleagues. Typical for Sokolov’s novels, the line between life and death fades away.

Николай предсказывает собственную смерть от рук товарищей-рыбаков. Линия между жизнью и смертью стирается — типичное явление для романов Соколова.

explanatory intratextuality structure theme
рыбаря

Fisherman.

Рыбака.

деньжат

Colloquial: money.

Разговорное: деньги.

register/style
позвякивало

Colloquial word: to jingle every once in a while.

Разговорное: периодически звенеть.

register/style
разгладятся морщины у старика

To make this old man smile.

Заставить старого улыбаться.

explanatory
растопырит нетопырь

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

stylistic device sound
нетопырь

Mentioned again in Note XXVIII (R263/E201). Animal motif.

Летучие мыши встретятся далее в романе.

motif intratextuality
крылья

Wings are associated with death in the novel.

Крылья ассоциируются со смертью в романе.

symbol theme
скупердяем

Colloquial word: cheap-skate, miser, old screw, stingy.

Разговорное: скупой человек, жмот, скряга.

register/style
плесни, град, вздрок

Sokolov explains: “‘plesnut’ vzdrok’ means to pour to the edge of the glass. I have not found this word in the dictionaries, but I heard it more than once on the Volga, so it can be considered a regional, local word. However, the dictionaries have synonyms equal to it in expressiveness: vsklyan’, vsklen’, vskray, vzrez’, vzdroch’. Going to town, Ilya plans to have a nice rest there and rhetorically asks the city to be generous, in particular, to treat him with alcohol, to pour him, Ilya, a full glass, and, of course, not only one. I remember an ironic phraseologism about a heavy drinker: he doesn’t drink at all, but he pours a glass full (nalivaet vsklen’)” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “‘плеснуть вздрок’ значит - налить до края стакана. В словарях это слово я не нашел, но на Волге не раз слышал, наверное, его можно считать областным, местным. Однако в словарях наличествуют равные ему по выразительности синонимы: всклянь, всклень, вскрай, взрезь, вздрочь. Направляясь в город, Илья планирует славно там отдохнуть и риторически просит его быть щедрым, в частности, как следует угостить спиртным, налить ему, Илье, полный стакан, причем, разумеется, не один. Фразеологизм помню такой, иронический, про сильно пьющего человека: Не пьет совсем, а наливает всклень” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory language phraseologism
град

Archaism: city (город).

Архаизм: город.

archaism register/style
град

Archaism: city (город).

Архаизм: город.

archaism register/style
бобылкой

Colloquial: an unmarried, lonely (peasant) woman. She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

Разговорное: незамужняя, одинокая женщина-крестьянка. Она встречается далее в романе и обычно ассоциируется с Ориной.

character register/style
поскуластей, поласковей

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

sound stylistic device
Николай

A Nikolai different from Nikolay the Helper, introduced above. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality folklore religion
Плосков

A village in the Tver’ oblast. Ostanin provides several extensive lists explaining the novel’s geography and topography, which, like so much else in the novel, doesn’t always match up (17).

Деревня в Тверской области. Останин подробно разъясняет топографию и географию романа, которые, как и зачастую в других частях романа, не сходится с их описаниями в тексте.

location Russia
чертова

Colloquial: hellish, accursed, cursed, goddamned, buggered, sodding.

Разговорное: дьявольская, окаянная, проклятая.

register/style
прорва

Archaism: many, a host.

Архаизм: толпа, масса.

archaism register/style
поспешает не торопясь

Oxymoron.

Оксюморон.

poetic device
ради Христа

A connection to Luke 5:1–11 in which Jesus acquires his first disciples after aiding them during fishing. Also, a common begging expression: “Give for Christ’s sake.”

Отсылка на Луки 5:1-11, где Иисус приобретает двух учеников после помощи им в ловле рыбы. Также, используется людьми, просящими подаяние: “Подайте Христа ради”.

intertextuality bible religion
Судари

Archaism: a formal, respectful form of address for men.

Архаизм: формально-уважительное обращение к лицам мужского пола.

register/style archaism
плесы

Archaism: the part of a fish’s body that passes into its tail. Metonymy. Animal motif.

Архаизм: часть туловища рыбы, переходящая в хвост. Метонимия. Мотив животных.

archaism register/style poetic device motif
ибо

Literary/archaism: because, for.

Книжное/архаизм: потому что.

register/style archaism
веретена рябых облаков

Such metaphoric language does not match the context.

Метафорический стиль речи расходится с контекстом.

language
река

That is, the Volga.

То есть, Волга.

explanatory setting location
ладьи

A longship, such as those used by Vikings. Boat motif.

Продолговатое судно, как у викингов. Изображено ниже:

Мотив лодки.

motif
ладьи, что брюхатыми вдовами валяются, брошены

Metaphor.

Метафора.

poetic device
брюхатыми

Archaism: big-bellied, pregnant.

Архаизм: беременные.

register/style archaism
валяются

Colloquial: to lie around for a long time, to be ill.

Разговорное: долго лежать, болеть.

register/style
кверху

Throughout the novel, there is a tension between being pulled down toward the bottom of the river and a desire to rise up toward the firmament.

На протяжении романа наблюдается дилемма между тягой на дно реки и стремлением ввысь, к небесам.

theme
чумовые

Colloquial: crazed men.

Разговорное: сумасшедшие.

register/style
дай нам тем не менее на́ душу по хвосту, дай нам рыб не твоих, тем более

Plea, irony.

Мольба, ирония.

irony
горемыкам

Archaism/poetic: someone continually plagued by misfortunes.

Архаизм, поэтическое: человек, преследуемый несчастьями.

archaism register/style
Николай

A Nikolai different from Nikolay the Helper, introduced above. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8).
