The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
на мякине не объегорить

Set expression: на мякине не проведёшь (to deceive an intelligent person).

Устойчивое выражение: об опытном человеке, которого нельзя обмануть/перехитрить.

phraseologism
объегорить

Low: to deceive, to trick.

Просторечное: обмануть, провести, перехитрить.

register/style
вручает

To hand over. High: to entrust.

Отдать. Высокой стиль: доверить.

register/style
линю

Tench. Also known as the doctor fish. A fresh- and brackish-water fish. Animal motif. There is a possible allusion to the biblical episode of the multiplication of loaves and fish.

Линь, также известный как “рыба-доктор”. Водится в пресных и полупресных водоемах. Изображено ниже:

Мотив животных. Возможная отсылка к библейскому эпизоду умножения хлебов и рыб.

motif bible religion
Деться

Colloquial: to disappear, to get lost, to vanish.

Разговорное: пропасть, потеряться, исчезнуть.

register/style
прорва

Archaism: many, a host.

Архаизм: толпа, масса.

register/style archaism
един

“Edin” (single, unique) for “odin” (alone). A continuation of the individual/collective theme.

“Един” (единственный, уникальный) вместо “один” (в одиночестве).

language theme
Человек одинокий в дороге его

An4.

Ан4.

metrical pattern
Человек одинокий в дороге его

An echo of Mikhail Lermontov’s 1841 poem “I go out on the road alone…” Available in English and Russian here.

Отлоголок стихотворения Михаила Лермонтова “Выхожу я один на дорогу…” (1841). Доступно на английском и русском языках здесь.

intertextuality
синька

Blue pigment for dyeing. Colloquial: a state of true drunkenness. Also here, the color of the sky.

Синий пигмент или краситель. Разговорное: стадия глубокого опьянения. Здесь относится к синему цвету неба.

register/style explanatory
Волчьей

That is, the Volga River.

То есть, река Волга.

location setting
един

Again “edin” for “odin.” A continuation of the individual/collective theme.

“Един” (единственный, уникальный) вместо “один” (в одиночестве).

language theme
Николай

A Nikolai different from Nikolay the Helper, introduced above. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality religion folklore
добычи в деревянный декабрьский град

Alliteration (d).

Аллитерация (д).

sound stylistic device
декабрьский

Time.

Указывается на время действия.

time
град

Archaism: city (город).

Архаизм: город.

archaism register/style
стародавней

Archaism: age-old, ancient.

Архаизм: древний, старый, ветхий.

archaism register/style
клюкой

A walking stick. Archaism: deception, trickery.

Трость для ходьбы. Архаизм: обман, ложь.

archaism register/style
шавок

Colloquial: cur, small dog. Animal motif.

Разговорное: дворняга, мелкая собака. Мотив животных.

register/style motif
звезд

Ilya will reference many constellations throughout the novel (e.g., R206–207/E98–99). They also function as part of the tension between the pull downward and the desire to rise up that the characters experience. Constellation-heavens motif.

Илья нередко упоминает в романе созвездия (например, R206–207/E98–99). Они также играют роль в борьбе героев между тягой вниз и желанием подняться ввысь.

intratextuality motif
воссияло

Archaism: to begin to shine.

Архаизм: начать светить.

archaism register/style
Гурий-Охотник

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3). The name is Jewish and means "little lion" (gur 'aryeh). There may be a connection to Titian's Allegory of Prudence. Ostanin suggests that it may be linked to Gury Kazansky (ca. 1500-1563) (14). Animal motif.

character intertextuality
безо всяких обиняков

Set expression: openly, without beating around the bush.

Устойчивое выражение: напрямую, по сути.

phraseologism
Николаем

A Nikolai different from Nikolay the Helper, introduced above. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intertextuality intratextuality folklore religion
Плосковским

A village in the Tver’ oblast. Ostanin provides several extensive lists explaining the novel’s geography and topography, which, like so much else in the novel, doesn’t always match up (17).

Деревня в Тверской области. Останин подробно разъясняет топографию и географию романа, которые, как и зачастую в других частях романа, не сходится с их описаниями в тексте (17).

location Russia
обшаркаю

Low: to snuff out, to defeat.

Просторечное: победить, обойти.

register/style
смущу

Archaism: to embarass.

Архаизм: унизить, поставить в неловкое положение.

register/style
сказал кто-то вдруг

This intertwining of different (and often unidentified) voices is typical in Sokolov’s works.

Переплетение разных (часто неизвестных) голосов типично для работ Соколова.

structure
мудрует

Colloquial: to overcomplicate things, philosophize.

Разговорное: усложнять, умничать, мудрить.

register/style
Плосках

A village in the Tver’ oblast. Ostanin provides several extensive lists explaining the novel’s geography and topography, which, like so much else in the novel, doesn’t always match up (17).

A village in the Tver’ oblast. Ostanin provides several extensive lists explaining the novel’s geography and topography, which, like so much else in the novel, doesn’t always match up (17).

location Russia
Федор

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character religion foreign intratextuality
счетах

Abacus: a counting device. A Russian variant was used through the twentieth century.

Счеты, или абак: устройство для выполнения расчетов. Русские счеты использовались до конца двадцатого века. Изображено ниже:

explanatory
То есть Федор не Федор, а как бы Петр. А уж Егор-то — во всяком случае

Again a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o”. A prime example of what Leona Toker calls Sokolov’s “forking characters” (“Gamesman’s Sketches” 354).

В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных “е/ё” и “о”. Яркий пример того, что Л. Токер называет “расходящимися (разветвляющимися) персонажами” (Toker “Gamesman’s Sketches” 354).

theme character
числилась

The verb aptly derives from the word “chislo” (number).

Глагол образован от существительного “число”.

language
счетовед

Misspelling of accountant: счетовод. Most likely, however, Fyodor/Petr/Yegor is not an accountant but a cashier.

Ошибка в написании слова “счетовод”. Скорее всего, однако, Федор/Петр/Егор не бухгалтер (счетовод), а кассир.

explanatory neologism language
но и он

Stealing is a common habit for the characters of the novel. Moreover, this is a palindrome.

Воровство — распространенная привычка героев романа. Более того, это палиндром.

explanatory poetic device character
как впоследствии выяснилось

The timeframe of the novel blurs.

Временные рамки романа стираются.

time
хоть куда

Colloquial expression: first-rate, excellent, terrific.

Разговорное выражение: первоклассный, отличный, искусный.

phraseologism register/style
Гурию

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
эта дама явилась негаданно на косу

Theme of love and death, often connected with the sound repetition of -ta- (see Caramitti 2004).

Тематика любви и смерти. Часто эта тема соприкасается со звуковым повтором -та- (см. Карамитти 2004).

theme
эта дама

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

Орина.

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
негаданно

Colloquial: unexpectedly.

Разговорное: неожиданно.

register/style
косу

Braid, scythe, or sandback/spit. The ambiguity of the word “kosa” has a famous literary “predecessor” in Aleksandr Blok’s drama Balaganchik (The Puppet Show, 1906). The female character of Columbine has a “kosa” behind her back: either a hair braid or a scythe. The “mystics” warn Pierrot about her being Death, but he calls her his bride (“Я не слушаю сказок. Я — простой человек. Вы не обманете меня. Это — Коломбина. Это — моя невеста”; I don’t listen to fairy tales. I am a simple man. You will not deceive me. This is Columbine. This is my bride). The ambiguity is also stressed by the character of the Author who enters the scene and exclaims: “Я не признаю […] аллегорической игры словами: неприлично называть косой смерти женскую косу! Это порочит дамское сословие!” (I do not recognize […] such allegorical wordplay: it is indecent to call a woman’s braid a scythe of death! It denigrates a lady’s status!). In the end, Pierrot sadly discovers that this Columbine was just a “cardboard bride” (Она картонной невестой была). The crucial theme linking a woman’s love to death draws parallels between Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s Balaganchik, although there is a very long literary tradition that has developed this line (e.g., Eros and Thanatos; Catullus’s Odi et amo, I hate and I love). Read the original by Blok here.

Отмель или мыс, а также сплетенные пряди волос или орудие для кошения травы. См. также “Балаганчик” А. Блока.

language intertextuality theme
сидни

Colloquial: couch potato, lazy-bones.

Разговорное: лентяи, бездельники.

register/style
весной

Time setting (spring).

Время действия романа (весна).

time
гусиный лет

Throughout the novel, geese are associated with sexual arousal. Here, they are linked to the Dama’s appearance in the hunters’ company. Although today far more commonly considered silly or stupid, geese have a lofty mythology. The goose has been traditional viewed as “an erotic symbol for both sexes, because it was the bird of creation, whether in the male solar form of the gods or the female lunar form of the mother goddesses” (Rowland, Birds 68). Similar connections between geese, sexuality, and foolishness appear elsewhere in the novel (R210, 221/E106, 125). Animal-human motif.

На протяжении романа, гуси ассоциируются с сексуальным возбуждением. Здесь, они связаны с появлением Дамы в компании охотников. Несмотря на современное восприятие гусей как глупых существ, мифологическая история этих птиц весьма благородна. Гуси традиционно воспринимались как “эротический символ обоих полов, будь то в форме солнца, олицетворяющего мужских богов, или луны, олицетворяющей богинь-матерей” (Rowland 68). Подобные связи между гусями, сексуальностью и глупостью встречаются далее в романе (R210, 221/E106, 125).

motif folklore intratextuality
сидении

Colloquial: a sitting spot.

register/style
купинах

This scene appears to be a ekphrastic depiction of Vasily Perov’s famous painting The Hunters at Rest (1871),

Эта сцена появляется в экфрастическом изображении картины Василия Перова “Охотники на привале” (1871), изображено ниже:

intertextuality
сумраках

Again, the twilight hour brings confusion and uncertainty to the novel’s events. Writing about A School for Fools, Dmitry Danilov says that in his art Sokolov captures “a world of uncertainty that is a world of continuous cognition that fails to ossify” (“Shkola neopredelennosti”).

Вновь, час сумерек вносит смятение и неопределенность в события романа. Описывая Школу для дураков, Д. Данилов замечает, что Соколов в своем творчестве запечатлевает “мир неопределенности — мир непрерывного, не успевающего закостенеть познания” (Danilov, “Shkola neopredelennosti” 4).

time theme
сокровенно

Literary/high: secret, concealed

Литературное/высокий стиль: скрытый, затаенный.

register/style
косе

Braid, scythe, or sandback/spit. The ambiguity of the word “kosa” has a famous literary “predecessor” in Aleksandr Blok’s drama Balaganchik (The Puppet Show, 1906). The female character of Columbine has a “kosa” behind her back: either a hair braid or a scythe. The “mystics” warn Pierrot about her being Death, but he calls her his bride (“Я не слушаю сказок. Я — простой человек. Вы не обманете меня. Это — Коломбина. Это — моя невеста”; I don’t listen to fairy tales. I am a simple man. You will not deceive me. This is Columbine. This is my bride). The ambiguity is also stressed by the character of the Author who enters the scene and exclaims: “Я не признаю […] аллегорической игры словами: неприлично называть косой смерти женскую косу! Это порочит дамское сословие!” (I do not recognize […] such allegorical wordplay: it is indecent to call a woman’s braid a scythe of death! It denigrates a lady’s status!). In the end, Pierrot sadly discovers that this Columbine was just a “cardboard bride” (Она картонной невестой была). The crucial theme linking a woman’s love to death draws parallels between Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s Balaganchik, although there is a very long literary tradition that has developed this line (e.g., Eros and Thanatos; Catullus’s Odi et amo, I hate and I love). Read the original by Blok here.

theme language intertextuality
принимают

That is, drink. Alcohol theme.

То есть, пьют.

explanatory theme
дама

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
которого я ищу

As will become clearer eventually, the Dame appears to be a form of Orina. She searches for Ilya.

Как становится ясно далее, Дама оказывается одной из форм Орины. Она ищет Илью.

explanatory character
плечьми

Archaism: shoulders.

Архаизм: плечами.

archaism register/style
что мы все хоть куда и готовы на все про все, лишь бы потрафить тебе, приворотнице наших мест

The lady is also a witch and is related to death and madness.

Дама - это ведьма. От нее смерть и безумие.

theme
хоть куда

Colloquial expression: first-rate, excellent, terrific.

Разговорное выражение: первоклассный, отличный.

phraseologism register/style
потрафить

Low/colloquial: to please, to oblige, to satisfy.

Просторечное/разговорное: угодить, удовлетворить.

register/style
приворотнице

Dialectical: enchantress.

Диалектическое: волшебница, колдунья.

register/style
Петра

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality foreign religion
счетоведа

Misspelling of accountant: счетовод. Most likely, however, Fyodor/Petr/Yegor is not an accountant but a cashier.

Неправильное написание слова “счетовод” (бухгалтер). Скорее всего, однако, Федор/Петр/Егор не бухгалтер, а кассир.

explanatory
колотун

Colloquial: cold, shivers, trembling.

Разговорное: озноб, дрожь.

register/style
полыхнул

Colloquial: to blaze, to flame up.

Разговорное: вспыхнуть, загореться.

register/style
И промолвил, подымаясь

Anaphora.

Анафора.

sound
подымаясь

Low: to get up, to arise.

Просторечное: поднимаясь.

register/style
отряхиваясь

To shake off, but also used to describe animals spreading their fur or feathers by shaking their body. Animal motif.

Также используется для описания животных, распушающих шерсть или растопыривающих перья путем встяхивания тела.

motif
впопыхах

Colloquial: in a hurry, hurriedly, helter-skelter, hastily.

Разговорное: торопливо, поспешно.

register/style
Он промолвил, подымаясь

Anaphora.

Анафора.

sound
подымаясь

Low: to get up, to arise. Characters in the novel often feel a pull to rise up but are often pulled back to the ground, to earth.

Просторечное: поднимаясь. Герои романа часто чувстуют стремление подняться, но вновь оказываются притянутыми обратно к земле.

register/style theme
сырой земли

“Moist Mother Earth” is the personified representation of the earth in Slavic mythology. It is also the title of a povest’ (novella) by Boris Pil’nyak (1925). Olga Matich already pointed out at the similarities between Pil’nyak’s text “about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War” and Between Dog and Wolf: “It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312).

symbol intertextuality
куда ему было уйти в скромном будущем

A prediction of his death (associated with the Dame) in the near future.

Предсказание его скорой смерти (связанной с Дамой)

time explanatory theme
скромном будущем

Ilya uses “modest” (скромное) as opposed to near (скорое) with future.

Илья использует “скромное” вместо “скорое” для описания будущего.

explanatory
Егор

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality foreign religion
Плосков

A village in the Tver’ oblast. Ostanin provides several extensive lists explaining the novel’s geography and topography, which, like so much else in the novel, doesn’t always match up (17).

Деревня в Тверской области. Останин подробно разъясняет топографию и географию романа, которые, как и зачастую в других частях романа, не сходится с их описаниями в тексте (17).

Russia location
веди

Archaism: the name of the Cyrillic letter В.

Архаизм: название буквы В в кирилице.

archaism register/style
дама

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
сидни

Colloquial: couch potato, lazy-bones.

Разговорное: лентяи, бездельники.

register/style
Петру

Yegor’s name changes to Pyotr and then to Fyodor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Имя “Егор” сменяется на “Петр”.

explanatory character intratextuality foreign religion
косу

Braid, scythe, or sandback/spit. The ambiguity of the word “kosa” has a famous literary “predecessor” in Aleksandr Blok’s drama Balaganchik (The Puppet Show, 1906). The female character of Columbine has a “kosa” behind her back: either a hair braid or a scythe. The “mystics” warn Pierrot about her being Death, but he calls her his bride (“Я не слушаю сказок. Я — простой человек. Вы не обманете меня. Это — Коломбина. Это — моя невеста”; I don’t listen to fairy tales. I am a simple man. You will not deceive me. This is Columbine. This is my bride). The ambiguity is also stressed by the character of the Author who enters the scene and exclaims: “Я не признаю […] аллегорической игры словами: неприлично называть косой смерти женскую косу! Это порочит дамское сословие!” (I do not recognize […] such allegorical wordplay: it is indecent to call a woman’s braid a scythe of death! It denigrates a lady’s status!). In the end, Pierrot sadly discovers that this Columbine was just a “cardboard bride” (Она картонной невестой была). The crucial theme linking a woman’s love to death draws parallels between Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s Balaganchik, although there is a very long literary tradition that has developed this line (e.g., Eros and Thanatos; Catullus’s Odi et amo, I hate and I love). Read the original by Blok here.

intertextuality theme language
Петра

As above with Nikolay/Nikola, here, Pyotr is addressed as Petra. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Как и в случае с именем Николай/Никола, к Петру обращаются как Петра.

character intratextuality foreign religion
Сидни

Colloquial: couch potato, lazy-bones.

Разговорное: лентяи, бездельники.

register/style
Федора

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality foreign religion
дамой

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Федора

Yegor/Pyotr becomes Fyodor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Имя Егора/Петра сменяется на Федор.

character explanatory intratextuality foreign religion
волкари

Hunters, wolfmen.

Охотники (на волков).

explanatory
слаще ли браги тебе побывать у нее обломилось?

Dak6.

Дак6.

metrical pattern
браги

Home-brew, hooch. The skaldic god of poetry in Norse mythology. A city in Portugal. Alcohol theme.

Бражка — самодельный алкогольный напиток. Бог-скальд поэзии в скандинавской мифологии. Город в Португалии. Тема алкоголя.

intertextuality location foreign theme
обломилось

Low: to get, to acquire, fall into.

Просторечное: случилось, пришлось.

register/style
Петр

His name returns to Pyotr. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Имя возвращается к первоначальному — Петр.

character intratextuality foreign religion
крамбамбули

An alcoholic drink typically made with red wine and other liquors such as gin, vodka, or rum. Made famous in Russia by Nikolai Iazykov’s translation of Christoph Friedrich Wedekind’s song “Kraumbambuli.” Derived from the Old High German word Kranawitu or chranawita and the Rotwelsch word Blamp. Alcohol theme.

Алкогольный напиток из красного вина и иных напитков, таких как джин, водка или ром. Стал известен в России благодаря переводу песни Христофа Фридриха Ведекинда “Крамбабули” Николаем Языковым. Образовано от старонемецкого Kranawitu или Chranawita и ротвельшского Blamp. Тема алкоголя.

foreign music theme
время минувшее

Literary: past.

register/style
крамбамбули

An alcoholic drink typically made with red wine and other liquors such as gin, vodka, or rum. Made famous in Russia by Nikoal Iazykov’s translation of Christoph Friedrich Wedekind’s song “Kraumbambuli.” Derived from the Old High German word Kranawitu or chranawita and the Rotwelsch word Blamp. Alcohol theme.

foreign music theme
Федор

His name returns to Fyodor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Его имя снова становится Федор.

character foreign intratextuality religion
вскипев

Colloquial: to become enraged, to flare up.

Разговорное: вспылить, разозлиться.

register/style
гнилухи

Alcoholic drink. Alcohol theme.

Алкогольный напиток. Тема алкоголя.

explanatory theme
валдайской

A town located in Novgorod Oblast first mentioned in a chronicle in 1495 and known for the manufacture of bells in eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Mentioned several times throughout the novel (R150, 155, 198, 230, 272/E2, 11, 87, 88, 140, 214).

Город в Новгородской области, впервые упоминается в летописи 1495 года. Известен литьём ямщицких колокольчиков в XVIII-XIX вв. Неоднократно упоминается в романе (R150, 155, 198, 230, 272/E2, 11, 87, 88, 140, 214).

Russia location music intratextuality
валдайской все выгорело

Alliteration (v).

Аллитерация (в).

sound stylistic device
Приняли

That is, drink. Alcohol theme.

То есть, выпили. Тема алкоголя.

explanatory theme
Петра

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intratextuality
с бухты-барахты

Set expression: suddenly, unexpectedly.

Устойчивое выражение: неожиданно, внезапно.

phraseologism
зазнобе

Archaism/poetic: sweetheart, object of affection.

Архаизм/поэтическое: любимый/ая, предмет обожания.

archaism register/style
былое

Archaism/poetic: the past, yore.

Архаизм/поэтическое: прошлое, минувшее.

archaism time register/style
похерено

Archaism: dashed, destroyed, cancelled, ruined, squashed.

Архаизм: уничтожено, разрушено, разбито.

archaism register/style
ибо

Literary/archaism: because, for.

Архаизм: потому что.

archaism register/style
сулят

Bookish/high: to promise.

Литературное/высокий стиль: обещать.

register/style
память не в дебет, брат, в кредит

Elena Kravchenko writes: “Ilya’s bookkeeping metaphor – memory is transferred into credit, not debit – paradoxically also points to an element of enrichment and solvency. An act of remembering is always a creative act” (“Between Dog and Wolf” 275–276).

theme
дебет, брат, в кредит

Lexicon used by accountants.

Бухгалтерская терминология.

register/style language
Пожилых

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character intertextuality religion
ка

Colloquial, the suffix is added to imperatives to express urgency.

Частица, добавляемая к императивам для выражения неотложности.

register/style
некогда

Literary: once, at some point.

Литературное: однажды.

register/style
крушение на скоростях

This crash can refer figuratively to Ilya’s death, the dissolution of his relationship with Orina, or his accident on the train tracks, in which he loses a leg. Railroad theme.

Это крушение может образно относиться к смерти Ильи, его разрыву отношений с Ориной или инциденту на железной дороге, в результате которого он лишается ноги. Тема железной дороги.

explanatory character theme
поперло

Colloquial: to push forward, work out, be on a roll (luck out).

Разговорное: продвигаться вперед, испытывать удачу.

register/style
тебе, Зынзырелла Илья

Ilya will often refer to himself in the second and third person. Unlike in English-speaking communities, it is more common to order Russian-originated names in this order: surname then first name.

Илья часто обращается к себе во втором и третьем лице. Интересно также необычный порядок имени: фамилия, затем имя собственное.

explanatory
Зынзырелла

Again an unusual last name (which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book). It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker’s essay, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356). However, as Korovashko suggests, “Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella ‘squared’: if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence” (277).

character intertextuality
Илья

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
покоробило

Literally: Ilya’s accident on the train tracks and his loss of a leg. Railroad theme.

Буквально: относится к аварии Ильи на железной дороге и его утере ноги. Тема железной дороги.

explanatory theme
Кантовались

Colloquial: to spend time, to reside somewhere.

Разговорное: проводить время, временно где-либо находиться.

register/style
вольготным

Colloquial: free, carefree, at ease.

Разговорное: свободный, беззаботный, ничем не стесненный.

register/style
у Орины в норе, позабыв про печали с печатями

An5GD.

Aн5ГД.

metrical pattern
Орины

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
норе

Refers to Orina’s modest living arrangements, but this term is also used to describe animals’ holes and burrows, thus creating yet another animal-human link. Animal-human motif.

Здесь используется для описания скромных жилищных условий Орины, но может также относиться к укрытиям животных, тем самым создавая очередную связь между животными и людьми. Мотив животных-людей.

motif explanatory
печали с печатями

Official marriage.

Официальный брак.

explanatory pun
печали с печатями

Alliteration (pech).

Аллитерация (печ).

sound stylistic device
по-гладкому катилась наша приязнь

Love is described as skating.

Любовь описывается как катание на коньках.

register/style poetic device
втерпеж

Derived from the colloquial невтерпёж (lacking patience). Here, Ilya suggests that his relations with Orina were going smoothly and patiently (i.e., calmly) for some time. Alexander Boguslawski notes that variations on this word are used in four key moments in the novel (R155, 157, 225, 254/E12, 14–15, 132, 185) and that the “close parallels between the first and last use of the phrase should be noted — this is the frame within which two other versions of the expression exist. These two framing elements are built around the word nevterpezh, a colloquial adverb, usually used after a noun or pronoun in dative case and often with auxiliary verbs to be or to become. Thus, the expression “mne stalo nevterpezh” [it became unbearable to me; I could not stand it any longer], [sic] is common. However, Sokolov makes some important alterations to the expression — first, he discards the dative government and substitutes another verb for the auxiliary” (“How Sokolov’s” 218).

explanatory neologism register/style intratextuality
втерпеж. Невтерпеж

Rhythmic repetition (semi-anadiplosis).

Ритмический повтор (семи-анадиплосис).

stylistic device rhythm
стрелки

In the sense of a railway switch. Trains play crucial thematic and narrative roles in all of Sokolov’s novels. Here, Orina is moved from one job to another, but more generally, the train switch symbolizes the characters’ many possible paths and multiple identities. Railroad theme.

В смысле железнодорожного стрелочного перевода. Поезда играют ключевую тематическую и повествовательную роль во всех повестях Соколова. Здесь, Орина меняет место работы, но, в более широком смысле, железнодорожная стрелка символизирует многочисленные личности героев и разнообразие их возможных жизненных путей. Изображено ниже:

Тема железной дороги.

theme explanatory symbol
курьерские, скорые и тому подобные

Different kinds of trains. Railroad theme.

Разновидности поездов.

explanatory theme
шуры-мурами

Colloquial: love affairs, flings, hook-ups.

Разговорное: любовные интриги, роман на стороне.

register/style
впротык

Colloquial word: good, well.

register/style
мою кралю в кирпичную башню

This phrasing may carry an echo of Rapunzel’s tale (the maiden in the tower).

Можно здесь угадать намек на сказку “Рапунцель”.

intertextuality
кралю

Archaism: queen. Colloquial word: beautiful, wealthy woman.

Архаизм: королева. Разговорное: красивая, богатая женщина.

archaism register/style
мурлыкал

Purred. Another animal association with Ilya. Animal-human motif.

Очередная ассоциация Ильи с животными.

motif
Илья

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality folklore character
пел Отраду, живет, говорил, в терему

Nineteenth-century song “Otrada” (“Joy”) with lyrics by Sergei Ryskin and music by Mikhail Shishkin. The song describes the singer’s love for a woman who is locked away in a high tower, echoing Orina’s displacement from Ilya. Listen here. Ilya references the same song in chapter 6 (R190/E72-73). “Терем” refers to a tower-room, that is, living quarters in the topmost part of a building shaped like a tower. Common in ancient Rus’:

Написанная в 19 веке песня “Живет моя отрада”, слова С. Рыскина, музыка М. Шишкина. В песне поется о любви певца к женщине, запертой в высокой башне, намекая на разлуку Ильи и Орины. Послушать можно здесь. Илья упоминает ту же песню в главе 6 (R190/E72-73). Терем — жилое помещение в верхней части башнеподобных зданий. Распространено на Древней Руси:

explanatory intertextuality Russia intratextuality music
терему

A tower-room, that is, living quarters in the topmost part of a building shaped like a tower. Common in ancient Rus’:.

Терем — жилое помещение в верхней части башнеподобных зданий. Распространено на Древней Руси:

Russia
чая

Archaism: to expect, to hope.

Архаизм: надеяться, ожидать.

archaism register/style
допетрил

Colloquial/low: to catch on, to realize, to understand.

Разговорное/просторечное: понять, осознать, сообразить.

register/style
узловатою

Ilya uses the word for “knotty” rather than “junction” (Boguslawski, “Annotations” 234).

Илья использует слово “узловатый” вместо “узловой” (Богуславский, “Аннотации” 234).

explanatory language
сцепщиками

Workers who couple train cars. Railroad theme.

Рабочие по сцепке вагонов. Тема железной дороги.

explanatory theme
стакнулась

Colloquial: to make secret arrangements with, to gang up.

Разговорное: тайно вступить в соглашение, сговориться.

register/style
если и не было в башню хода кому — так только тебе, милок

A replay of the nineteenth-century song “Otrada” (“Joy”) with lyrics by Sergei Ryskin and music by Mikhail Shishkin. The song describes the singer’s love for a woman who is locked away in a high tower, echoing Orina’s displacement from Ilya. Listen here. Ilya references the same song in chapter 6 (R190/E72-73).

Отсылка к написанной в XIX века песне “Отрада”, слова С. Рыскина, музыка М. Шишкина. В песне поется о любви певца к женщине, запертой в высокой башне, намекая на разлуку Ильи и Орины. Послушать можно здесь. Илья упоминает ту же песню в главе 6 (R190/E72-73).

intertextuality music
допетрив

Colloquial/low: to catch on, to realize, to understand.

Разговорное/просторечное: понять, осознать, сообразить.

register/style
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il'ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il'ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il'ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312).
